div.p: Powers to be Resisted: OR A DIALOGUE ARGVING The Parliaments lawfull Resistance of the Powers now in Armes against them; And that Archbishops, Bishops, Curates, Neuters, all these are to be cut off by the Law of God; Therefore to be cast out by the Law of the Land.

Very necessary and usefull for the information of the ignorant, confirmation of the weake, stablishing of the strong, convincing of the froward, in the clearing, resolving, and stating the legality of the Covenant, and this present Warre.
Also an Answere to this Quere, How farre Religion may be defended by the Law of Armes? being a thing much questioned by some.

Here is also a fit Answere to Dr FERNS late Answer, such as God hath commanded to be given unto him, who (in the Title and Close of his book) hath exalted his Folly, and his wickednesse before the face of all the Christian world.

div.head: POWERS TO BE RESISTED. Or a Dialogue arguing the PARLIAMENTS lawfull resistance of the Powers now in Armes against them.

p.hi: Am very unresolved in point of resisting the powers.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Distinguish of Powers, and you may be resolved, please you: There are Powers appointed for the good of man, his safeguard and protection: There are Powers pointed directly to the hurt of man, his spoyling and destruction: Powers of light, for God is light▪ Powers of darknesse; and Powers also within a man ruling in darknesse, self-will, and carnall reason.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But, there is no power but of God; the powers that are, are Rom. 13.1, 2. ordained of God. Therefore no resisting, as it follows.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is sacred Scripture, therefore a sacred Truth; no Power, whether Supr • me or Subordinate, but is of God; appointed by God; for what? To bee a terror to evill workes, and workers: A comfort and encouragement to good workes and good men. But there are Powers not Supreme nor sub-ordinate, that are as contrary to all this, as evill is to good, (which, in a large sence, may be said to bee of God too) pointed as aforesaid▪ to destroy man, made in the Image of God. These are principalities and powers, and Devills they are. Powers also there are within a man, self-will and carnall reason, very evill Spirits also, serving to execute the Divells pleasure, whereof we shall heare more anon, and the clearest proofe, That these must be resisted.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
You are in the Clouds already, and above them, too high for me▪ If you would have men understand you, you must speake low and plaine words, that
may be felt, heard, and understood. This is it, wherein I would be fully, plainly and clearly resolved: Where the Law is, which seales your Warrant to resist the King?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Indeed I would not have had you have mentioned the King; But since you have done it, we will make as honourable mention of the King as we can; and turne off all the envy to another thing, that Lords-it over the King and would Lord-it over his people too (which shall never be) and hinc ill • e lachrim • e, hence all our sorrows. But before I passe on, I must stand still and wonder. A wonderfull thing! that you will never bee satisfied; Is there not answer after answer unto that, which clears the lawfullnesse of our resistance, as the noone day?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, yee never yeelded so far, nor granted yee hitherto, That yee resisted the King, though you be up in Armes against him, Say I.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: For him, say we; for we will never yeeld, that wee resist the King: we will maintaine a lawfull resistance, which God blesseth: and abhor the contrary, which God curseth.

p.hi: What Resistance is that?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: A resistance of a private will, active enough of its self, but made more active being stirred up by that evill Spirit, which rules mightily in the world now a dayes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I smell out your distinction now, you distinguish betwixt what the King does as Lord over us; and what his will does, as Lord over him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes, for there is a wide difference betwixt what a King does by Law: and what his Will does without, or against Law.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But I will hold to this still, The King can doe no wrong.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: And I to this still; That selfe-will, carnall Reason, (call it what you will, an evill Spirit it is) has done wrong, does doe wrong, and will do all the mischiefe it Can doe, while it is its selfe, and rules in a man; This will, this Carnall reason, saies oneBernard Oc • i. Ser. 3. was the Serpent in the Garden, and so he goes on, telling us what Carnall will has done, throughout the sacred Chronicle: and we could carry on the Story throughout our Chronicles all up to, as it does at this day.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, let will doe what it will doe, we allow no resistance.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No resistance man! You forget your selfe sure, you do hold That your owne will and Carnall reason is to be resisted.

p.hi: No indeed not I.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No indeed not you! Then you doe, what you have a will to doe, what Carnall reason dictates to be done, and then you are a very Rebell, Ier. 3.5. you doe evill with both hands, as you can; so choaking Conscience as you may. Remember your self, man, and you will yeeld presently, that there is a wide difference betwixt what you doe, and what you ought to doe, and that you ought to resist your own will.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ought not, I thinke, for I suppose, that will is the chiefe and supreame faculty in man; and why ought not [to doe as the highest Commands mee?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Will is indeed supreme in you, for it will be so; It is a Rebell, an Usurper, and that will perch above its betters, and controule them. But you must know, that the understanding is the supreme faculty, though the will can over-power it (because That faculty also has lost its dignity:) I say, the will over-rules the understanding many times, (but that argueth the impotence of the will) for when the understanding has resolved the case, and the best way, in giving sentence as supreme; then the will can resolve against it, and follow a crosse way, according to its owne determination, after the understanding, has given its verdict; and so in a short time will can put out the light in the understanding, set up for a guide there, as in a watch Tower, and choake the mouth of Conscience quite. Therefore thus I argue; You ought to resist your greatest enemy, that you have upon the Earth, or in the Aire (where evill Spirits are) or in the bottomlesse-pit, where their King is: But self-will or Carnall Reason is the greatest Enemy of any you have in any of these quarters, Earth, Aire, or Hell, therefore selfe will is to be resisted.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I know whereto you drive now; That a man, being himselfe, Cast into the lap of his owne will, let alone to guide his owne steps, to hold his owne r • ines, that such a man is the greatest enemy to himself.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Yes indeed is he, and as certainly so, as twice three is six: It were an easier Judgment for a man to bee delivered-up to Satan, the Devill, That Adversary, then to be delivered-up to his owne Will, to bee let alone to walke in his owne way; the former may tend to the destruction of the flesh;
Cor. 5.5. the latter tends directly to the destruction of the soule.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, and what if I grant so much, and that I am he, the greatest enemy to my selfe, what then? who has to doe with that? and wbat if I grant too, that I must resist my selfe, my carnall reason, it does not follow that therefore the King is to be resisted.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No, I argue not for that resistance, against it rather, but it followes, selfe-will is to be resisted.

p.hi: Yes, so it does not relate to the King.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
So it does not relate to the King! you will be medling still, and so make the case more cleare against you: Selfe-will is rather, and more to be resisted in a King then in a private person: for in a private person, though it be the greatest enemy he has, yet it may hurt but himselfe onely: but selfe-will in a King is indeed his owne greatest enemy, but being let alone and not resisted, may destroy three kingdomes: Therefore selfe-will commanding in a King is more and
rather to be resisted then in another man.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, I say againe, and will stand to it, let Selfe-will be King in a King, and let it doe what it will doe, Ile allow no resistance, no kinde of resistance, none at all.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Now you have spoken out, and wisely you thinke, when indeed you speake foolishly; You will allow no resistance, non at all! It is but your will, you have no reason for it at all no not common reason; you have not choaked that yet; does not your reason tell you. that the devill is to be resisted? Remember your selfe, man, you doe hold it lawfull to resist the divel, doe you not?

p.hi: Yes, now I remember my selfe, I doe hold that resistance lawfull, though I resist him not; and if I should hold the contrary, you would hold that the divel were in me, he held and possessed me.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I should hold so indeed; but from what you grant, I inferre, That it is lawfull t • resist a private will, where ever it commands, but more especially in publike persons, as are a King and Queene Regent: That which is private in private persons, is publike in them, so publike person:s and so the rather to be resisted by publike persons; I mean those, who are to see unto it, that Law governs and not Will.

p.hi: That I deny now, your inference I meane.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I shall prove it; but let us understand first what Selfe-will is. It is nothing else but the Manager of the Divels and his Bishops affaires here on earth; their agent and factour it is here in the world; so it hath been in all ages, so it is at this day: The Divel cast the Saints into prison once; so he doth now: It was not the Divel then in person, nor is it he now: The divel did it then by the managers of his wrath, his evill servants, and so he does the very same now: he does cast the Saints into prison now, into the fire and water now, yet not he in propriety of speech, but the Manager of his wrath, selfe-will, egged-on by an evill spirit, so potent in the world as aforesaid: The devill delights in proud wrath, and so he did from the beginning, and time was when with his owne hands (as I may say) he exercised the same wrath, when he made poore creatures, men, and women, and children (the object of his wrath ever; for when hee destroyed the Gadarens Swine, it was with an intention to destroy the Gadarens; to grieve them so, that they might, in a discontent with their losse, throw away their blessing, bid their Lord God depart from them, and out of their coasts; when (I say) he made poore creatures) cruell and terrible, and fi • rce upon themselves; and when he cast the servants of the Lord, as he did the child into the fire, and into the water; all this he hath done with his owne hands. Now the divel works more secretly, cunningly, and wilily, (for we know his wiles and his depths;) he works by his agent now; he workes
and wins upon the Will mightily, gaines that, engageth that to be his ready servant, as his eldest Son, the first borne of his strength, and right-hand now in the world; and having done so, he doth his work with ease. Then, when the Will is gained, when that becomes a ready minister of Sathan; what then? Mat. 15.19. Mat. 7.21. then out-comes all that was in the heart; then that shop (sinke, hell rather) is opened, and out comes Murthers, Adulteries, blasphemies: Then Protestations are made, and Declarations shew themselves, and Proclamations issue forth, and Commissions are sealed (to warrant, I will not say what▪ but what the Divel wills) and a Pacification concluded; with whom? with the Divels eldest Sons, the very right-hands of the time; so all is done now to the Divels heart; as he would have it, so all is done, for he hath gained the Will. As it is when God has gained the Will (which he gained by speaking to it with a strong hand,
Isa. 8.11. for it is a stiffe and stubborne thing, as hardly turned backe in its way, as Jordan in its course; but when it is turned backe and gained) then the Will is presently Gods ready Minister, as the Angels are; it stands before the LORD, having its eares boared, wide open, and with its loines readie girt, to receive and doe according as its LORDS instructions and commands are, either for doing or suffering his Lords good will and pleasure: I say it againe, that it may be well observed, When the Will is turned by that Almighty hand, when it is gained by a creating Word from his mouth, then the Will sayes as Paul did. LORD, what wilt thou have me to doe? Doe but speake Lord;
Act. 9.6. if it be thy will that I shall goe through fire and water, I will goe; If it be thy command, and I know it to be thy command, I will not dispute, I will obey: I will not complaine, There is a Lyon in the way, while I am in my Lords way; nor will I aske any other question but this, LORD, what wilt thou have me to doe?

Thus it is with a man when God has gained his Will; and just so it is with a man when the Devill has gained his Will, the man is as ready a minister for the Devills service, his eares are boared, as wide open, and his loines are as ready girt to receive, and doe the Devils commands; without a complement, the man sayes to the Divell, Your servant, Sir; nay, Your Gregory▪ your thrice-humble Servant; Lord what wilt thou have me to do? I am at your beck, a nod is enough to signifie your pleasure; no sooner you have given an intimation thereof but it shall be done; a peace shall be concluded with the Irish monsters. Whence this readinesse? How comes it to passe, that a man, made in Gods image, is become now Servus servorum, a slave? how so? The Devill has gained his Will. Now we understand what Selfe-will is, and whose Servant it is, and what service it does in the world, and how ready and nimble it is upon
the Divells work; what the Divell motions and commands to bee done, it does, and it does it suddenly, being the Divells ready servant and right hand in the World.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I deny still, that selfe will is the Devills Servant.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You may deny that the Divell is a Divell, or that Satan is, as his name is an Adversary, that there is any evill in the heart, or poison in the Serpent; All this you may deny as reasonably as what you doe deny. But deny what you will deny, This is as well cleared a Truth, as any that shines in the World; That selfe will is the Divels greatest Centurion in the World, no such servant as selfe will▪ It Commands for the Divell, and to answer his pleasure, as tr •• love in the soul Commands for GOD: It Commands eyes, and eares, and hands, and feet, and all, come and they come, goe and they goe, doe this and that for the Divells service, and it does it: Will while it its selfe, and Regent in a man, is the Divells greatest Centurion upon Earth, it cannot reasonably be denyed.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You will have your saying, and what then? what if Selfe will will be the Devils Servant, what then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Then we must resist it, for if we must resist the Master, then the Servant sure, all law and reason in the World for that; If I must not suffer the Lord and Master to cut my Throat, I must not suffer his Servants sure to murther me; I must resist Will the Devils sl • ve: And which must not bee omitted; This resistance argueth the purest obedience, loyalty, duty and good service to the person, whose Will is resisted, that is Conceivable: so I have done.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But I have not done, I am where I was, and where I will bee, for this I affirme still; That if the King wills the impoverishing Cities, laying waste Townes, if his pleasure be, that his licenced Souldiers (Skilfull to destroy) shall have a Commission to doe what they have a will to doe, Plunder London. &c. yet my opinion is, there ought to bee no Resistance at all; and my honest Mr. Ferne holds fast my opinion too.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I thought how we should issue the point, for I know Dr. Ferne is your Master; and that folly will not depart from a foole, who thinks himself wiser then seven men, that can give a Reason. Notwithstanding I will try another Argument with you; and bray the foole anon a little more, to put him off from his opinion if it can be.

div.head: ARGUMENT II. It is lawfull to take a Sword out of a mad Mans hand, Is it not?

p.hi: Yes, for if I should deny that, you would say I were mad too; but what then?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Then it is lawfull to resist the Sword in an Adversaries hand.

p.hi: It is no cleare Consequence; you are to pray for your Enemy, and Adversary▪ I thinke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes, if he bee sober, or any hope by prayer to make him so; But if he be mad, ready to pluck out your Throat, if a double madnesse be in him, then you must resist him with all your power, must you not?

p.hi: Yes, if he be so mad; and had you said so at first, you had not been interrupted, but now you must prove the Enemy and Adversary to be mad.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That I argue thus; If the Enemy and Adversary does now in the cleare light and Sunshine of the Gospel against the Righteous,He is exceeding wicked, who doe • wickednes with a light in his hand. the same which Saul did in the dark and night of his ignorance, then the enemy is as Saul was, mad with rage: But the Adversarie does now in the light and sunshine of the Gospel, against the Kings best Subjects, the same that Saul did in the night of his ignorance against the Righteous; Therefore the Adversary is now, as Saul was then, mad with rage.

p.hi: I know not what you meane by this Adversary.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That is not to the purpose, but this is to the purpose, That hee is mad with rage.

p.hi: If you meane the King, I am resolved to grant nothing. I will not grant that the King is an adversary and Enemy, nor mad with rage.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Nor will I affirme it for a world; I will not speake against my Conscience. I cannot thinke That the King (as King) Can be an Enemy and Adversary to his Kingdome. But this I doe affirm, That the Adversary and enemy is mad▪ starke mad with rage, doubly mad▪ mad upon his Idols, and mad with rage; therefore wee must resist him.

p.hi: It rests in you to prove now, That the Adversary and enemy is mad with rage.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That is proved already, The enemy does as Saul did.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am as wise as I was before; I know not whom you meane, whether Saul the King, or Saul afterwards called Paul.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Take whom you will you cannot bee mistaken. They were both persecutors, only with this difference, th'one persecuted David (i. e. the faithfull of the Lord) in the darke night of his ignorance,
so God was gracious unto him, and he repented, but this Saul, while a persecutor, was mad with rage, and so hee saies of himself, when hee came to himself. The enemy does now as Saul did then, breathing out threatnings, &c. therefore he is mad with rage His thoughts say as much, Act. 9.1. & 26.11. made legible by his hand in the bloodiest Characters; his words are as Sauls were, hee breaths out threatnings (I speake of him single, though he is plurall, a legion, for he is many) he threatens to slaughter the righteous; so he breaths forth threatnings, and slaughters against the Disciples of the Lord, as Saul did when hee was mad with rage.

2. He persecutes the righteous as far as his hand will reach; hee makes havock of them; God, Angels and men are Witnesses, that so the Adversary and enemy does: and in the clearest light he does this, against all the laws of Heaven, and the clearest laws of all the Kingdomes on earth: Saul did so in the darke; but hee had a Law by which he did it too, yet when he came to himself and was sober, he acknowledgeth he was exceedingly mad with rage. The Adversarie does, this against all law, except the law of his own will, mad against the godly; Therefore it is lawfull to wrest the sword out of the Adversaries hand.

p.hi: Surely you meane the King all this while; Therefore I will recall all that was said and deny all.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I doe not meane the King; True it is, and let the King look to that, God chargeth all upon him, which he Commands, or suffers to be done: But I utterly deny that the King can do all as aforesaid, as King; he is King by that power, which God hath intrusted him with, and in reference thereunto, to bee obeyed: and therefore, as King over a free people, he cannot enslav •
his people, and destroy his Kingdome. I meane all this while the Enemy and Adversary, him, that has done all as abovesaid, and is starke mad with rage, and mad upon his Idols, therefore to be resisted.

p.hi: Why? bu • To deale with you in your owne Argument; though Saul did doe as indeed hee did, breath out threatnings and slaughters, yet the Disciples then did not wrest the Sword out of his hand, they committed the matter unto God, and suffered patiently.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
True, and there is good Reason for that, hinted before. For though Saul did what he did in the dark and night of his ignorance, yet hee did it by a Law in force then, and • ccording to order; hee had letters from the high Priest, which gave him Commission to enter into every house, and hale-men and women out thence, and commit them to prison, hee did make havock of the Church, hee cast abroad the rage of his wrath, but by virtue of the high Priests Warrant, which stood in force at that time: That, which the Adversary does now,
is in the clearest light, by warrant from the Pope their high Priest whom we stand bound to withstand, or by virtue of his own warrant and commission, which his owne will has framed against the clearest light from heaven, and the clearest Law and Reason upon earth: It is most cleare, That the Adversary and Enemy are doubly mad, mad upon their idols, and mad with rage; therefore it is not onely lawfull, but the greatest service that can bee done to them, or any one of them, to the private and common-wealth, To wrest the sword out of their hand, which is so destructive to the King and kingdome there.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But if there be a Kingly power with or in the Adversaries and Enemies hand, they must be obeyed as well when they are mad with rage, as when they are sober with reason.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have done: for though I know what to say more, yet more needs not; it is a mad mans objection, and he will receive no answere: yet if I would contend any longer, I would deny that a Kingly power (for by that I understand a lawfull power) can bee put-over into an adversaries hand.

p.hi: I speake the words of truth and sobernesse, ye are subjects, ye ought not to resist.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: We are subjects, not slaves; free-men, not Servants to the lusts and will of man: the Church has but one Leader, and he is their Commander; they stand charged to obey no other, but as he commands from Gods mouth; nor to follow any other, but as he leads unto Him.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Who shall be Iudge of this Commander and this Leading?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Not the Pope, nor his Church, but God and his Word; and I hope you are content to stand to that
•• ipirage.

p.hi: What ever their umpirage is, I will hold to that I first said, Ye are the Kings subjects, and must subject your selves to him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Ye •
〈◊〉 he subjects himselfe to God and his Law, no further.

p.hi: The King commands obedience, and will have it.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: God commands obedience, and must have it.

p.hi: I cannot examine the commands, the sword must decide i • , and let power carry it: All the Nations upon the earth are on the Kings side.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Yes, all the Nations that are angry against our side, because the Lord Christ has taken to himselfe power now; Rev. 11.17. all these are on the Kings side: and also all the sottish, bruitish Pastors and people all over the Christian world: All these are mad with rage, and on the Kings side too, (a mighty Argument to prevaile with every sober-man not to wheele-about turne taile, and joine with that side.) But yet, though such a multit ••• of many people are on the Kings side, and a rushing of Nations like the rus • ing of many waters, yet there are more on
the Churches side (the Parliaments side,) for the Lord their God is with them,
Num. 23.21, Isa. 17.13. and the shout of a King is amongst them. He shall rebuke th • se Nations among them: he shall chase them as the chaffe of the mountaines before the winde, and like a rolling thing before the whirlewind. The Church is assured it shall be so, she is not carefull about it. They do their duty, they ply their work, they know the cause shall be maintained; some maintaine it with a respect to their honour, some to their profits, the fewest in a pure zeale; but wee rejoice, and must rejoice in this, The cause is maintained, and shall be maintained; The cause must prosper; we know it must. There is a seeking people, who seeke not great things on earth, neither honours, nor profits, nor pleasures, nor long life, nor the life of their enemies for a prey, their conversion rather: They seeke, and they will seek, that Popery, and Prelacy may downe; That their Lord Christs throne may bee exalted: They seeke that the abomination of desolation▪ the Kings Army, may be removed; and yet not so much doe they seeke the remove of that generation of men▪ as that the accursed things may be removed out of the Land, which gives strength thereunto: They seeke not so much that the sword may be removed, as that the sinne may be removed, which has brought the sword, and furbished the same.

p.hi: But what will you say now if the Kings Majesty will be pleased to make a peace with you (as he has with the Irish) what will you say now if God will answere your prayers now, and bring him backe to his Parliament at last, as you have • rayed, and prayed, and prayed so oft?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly I never prayed for his comming to his Parliament; I prayed, and doe pray, as well as I can, that he may feele it to be an evill, and a bitter thing, That ever he departed from his Parliament, for ever since he has pursued the soules of the righteous, and their blood has pursued him. It is a good prayer for ought I can tell my selfe, LORD bring the King to his Parliament, but I could never close with that prayer, because I could not perswade my soule, That it is an orderly prayer▪ There is betwixt him and the Parliament, I will not say a gulfe, such as was betwixt Abraham and Dives, but I will say there are depths, even seas of bloods betwixt the King and his Parliament; And my prayer is, that the King may fall into those deeps that from thence he may cry unto the Lord to pardon the blasphemies of his.

p.hi: Peace, and consider what you are saying, weigh your words well.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I hav • considered, I have weighed them with all my heart and with all my soul, and I say the blasphemies of his Protestations, Proclamations, Declarations, Commissions, Pacifications. 1. He has protested That he stands for God, when he fights against the Almighty with all his
hands. 2. He has proclaimed warre with the Saints, all the excellent of the world, the best Subjects to the high God in heaven, and to his Vice-roy on earth. 3. He has declared himselfe for the true Religion with his mouth, and persecuted the true professors thereof with his hand. 4. He has sealed bloody Commissions for the destroying a mother-City in Israel, not for her transgression, Psal. 59.3. nor for her sinne, her Lord knowes: though there is much wickednesse within her, yet no •
• or that but because she stands up for God and His cause above all the Cities in the wor • d, and is a refuge for the out-casts, she lets them dw • ll with her, she is a cover to them from the face • f the spoiler; and it is her Lords command that so she must doe▪ she must entertaine strangers; But therefore we • e those Commissions grant • d for the cutting-off all her helpers within and succours from without. Remember how the wicked have blasphemed thy name, O Lord; And remember this City, O Lord, and all that shee has done for the advancing of Thy Name, and spare her according to the gre • tnesse of thy me • cy. Amen.

2. For the Peace (but vvhispered novv, and the last refuge) it is a cursed Peace: Thinke wee that God vvill endure to have his servants spoiled and killed, and &c. and then heare of making a peace vvith him: What Peace▪ God and His people all abominate that peace; such a Peace, and such Peace-makers are all an abomination to the Lord: let them that seeke peace make peace with their God first, lay hold on His Arme first, stay themselves there-on, and be at peace. Amen.

p.hi: You have not done yet, I doe entreat you before you leave to shew me the war • ant you have to maintaine Religion by the sword.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Ile shevv you our Warrant, if you vvill shevv us first what Warrant the adversary hath to persecute Religion vvith the svvord▪ to thrust the Lord Christ out of His Throne vvith the svvord; to thrust at the apple of His eye vvith the svvord; to thrust His people from His service vvith the svvord; to destroy a Mother-city in Israel vvith fire and svvord both; shevv us the adversaries Warrant for all this.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You may shew it your selves; it is but reading the Commission his Majesty sealed to his right-men, and good subjects, and sent up to London you know when: Therein is Warrant sufficient for doing as aforesaid; it is in full words expressed in the Commission, This shall be your Warrant to you and every one of you, to destroy a Mother-city in Israel.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: O monstrous! I remember that is the Warrant indeed, and to be abhorred with the soule: It is a Warrant to send a man to the Gallowes, (where hee may bee hanged vvith his pardon about his necke) and from thence to the place of execution, I meane to hell. But since you have dealt so ingenuously vvith me, in shevving me your Warrant, Ile shevv you our Warrant, to defend our persons from the povver of the svvord. The Law of Nature gives us this Warrant, To keep the Murtherer from our throats, To get our heads from under the foot of pride if wee can: The Lord God •• Mercies gives His poore Servants so much leave as Nature gives a poore vvorme, it vvill vvringle avvay from the foot, and earth it selfe. And this is the very Warrant that whole States have had in severall quarters of the vvorld, to vvrest themselves from-out the hand of violence, and are novv Free States at this day, proclaimed free by the Law of Armes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You have said, but not a word to purpose: you tell me Nature allowes to defend your person with the sword; you should answere my question, Whether it be lavvfull to defend Religion with the sword?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
It followes from the lesse to the greater; What! does the Lavv of Nations warrant us to defend our persons and states from the hand of violence, and does not the Law of God (not to speake of the Law
of Nations, for if the law of God bee on our side, we are sure, we have all the Lawes on our side, and does not) That Law warrant us to maintaine the Lawes of God, the Rights of his Kingdome, the Liberties and priviledges of His Subjects; The great Trust of the Kingdomes. To defend all these with the sword, against those, who would destroy, overthrow, make void, and null, all the laws of Gods Kingdome, and of His Kingdomes on the earth; does not the law of God give his people this warrant, to strive about these matters?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No, it is expresly said; The Servants of the Lord must not strive,2 Tim. 2.24. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
must not fight with the sword.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: True, they must be meeke and gentle; they must not fight one with another; Rom. 15 30. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . but they must fight the battels of the Lord, strive together with me, saies Paul.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Read on, in your prayers.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
It followes indeed, for they are the Churches most prevailing weapons, prayers and teares; But the Church has another weapon, and that is the Sword which her people have not a Law only, but an exhortation to use, earnestly contend for the faith, saies Iude,
Iude 3. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . the servant of Jesus Christ.

p.hi: What man! with the sword?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Yes man with the sword: if the adversary contends against the Common-salvation, against the Common Trust, and faith of the Kingdome, then we have our Exhortation, earnestly to contend (against this Adversary, with the Sword) for the faith. It is lawfull to contend with the sword, that's out of question. I call God, Angels and Men to record upon this now; That if it be lawfull in any case, then in this case, in our case, it is lawfull to Contend with the Sword for the Common salvation, for the Faith, the Common Trust of the Kingdome: If in any case lawfull to contend with the sword, then in this Case, I call God, Angels and men to witnesse here. Come, man, let us shew our sel • es men, and reason the case a little as reasonable men▪ Do we see a pearle (the pearle in the Gospel, is the Gospel, the Common Salvation, the Faith of the Kingdome) doe wee see this trod-under by Swine, Swinish men? Doe wee see this, or doe wee not see it?
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Surely, it must be answered, we doe see it. What! and doe wee not thinke it lawfull to Contend for it? To rescue a Pearle trod-under now by the feet of Pride, as Mire in the streets? Not lawfull to contend for a pearle (man) against the Swine of the Earth, Swine and Dogs.

p.hi: No not lawfull to contend against them with the Sword.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How then I pray you.

p.hi: With prayer.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Contend against Swine and Dogs with Prayer! I never heard the
like since I was borne. A vaine thing it is sure▪ To pray the Swine not to trample the pearle under foot: To pray the Dogs not to rent you; The Dogs are flying in your face, and you will pray them to be quiet; implacable Creatures! the more you pray, the more implacable they will bee. Let us remember what the Lord affirmes, though he puts it downe in way of Question; Job 41.2. The Leviathan will not make supplications to thee, he will not sp •• ke soft unto thee. Surely the Lords Servants may say as much of these Swine and Dogs, wee may make supplications unto them; wee may speake soft (words) unto them, they will not deale so with us.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Surely, you have no logick, if Reason bee logick; as they say it is: You doe not keepe ad Idem, what have wee to doe with Swine and Dogs, man, how fell you upon them?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: They fell upon us, and, and as our case stands, we have to do with none else in the World; Matth. 7. none else but Dogs will turne back, and rent you: None but Swine will trample a pearle under foot; it is a most cleared truth, cleared by our Lord Christ hims • lfe: That wee must Contend with these is granted; with what weapon, that is the question; with the sword I say; no, with Prayers you say: who is in the right? Judge you.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If by Swine and Dogs, you meane Swinish and bruitish men, I have nothing to reply.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: If I meane swinish and bruitish men! why you cannot mean any other: Matth 7 6. Eve • y Swine is a wicked man; but every wicked man is not a Swine; he only who opposeth Religion, tramples under the Pearle. These men only saith the Lord Christ, doe rent and teare His Servants! and trample their Pearle under-foot; And is it not very cleere unto you now, That Prayers will not move those kind of men, they must be removed with the Sw rd?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, very cleare; And I thanke you for your paines; surely now, that I kn w, who are Swine and Dogs, I shall never say againe, that such a generation of men, must be resisted with Prayers.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly I intend your information heartily, and resolved you at first, that I would be as plaine as possibly I could, and speake words that might be felt; but if any light has come into your understanding, you will praise God for that. We go on now, I will question you a little further▪ Doe you thinke that there are in our dayes any such men, that will rent and teare those who have the same image with them, and will trample a pearle under foot?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Thinke, say you; I know it as sure as there are swine and dogges in the land; lions, beares, wolves, in the world, so sure I know there are such a swinish brutish generation of men up in armes in our land. Indeed (Sir) I take it not well that you should put such a question unto me: True it is, through Gods good providence over me these dogges have not rent me, yet I am very sensible what they have done in Ireland, what in England, and what their
will and full purpose of heart is to doe: I am able also to consider how implacable they are; and what they doe to the pearle (by which you understand Religion) is very well knowne unto me; and what they have a will and full purpose of heart to doe, as their chaines shall be lengthened out unto them, and the bridle (upon their chaps, but the reines in Gods hand) shall be let-out: I know all this, as well as I know what fire will doe on the tops of houses, and a devouring flood in the time of harvest, which leaves no food.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Very well, blesse God for what you know, walke humbly before Him, and you shall know more every day; The Lord teacheth the meeke in his way, makes all light before them, whereas Hee leaves the proud in the darke, to blunder-on upon the drawne sword. And surely your Master Ferne is a great example of all this, which appears by an Answer he has lately sent from Oxford; you need not be at three Farthings cost to buy it, for the scope and tendency thereof is knowne to all the world; it is to make the King glad with lyes; to strengthen the hand of violence; to make the Adversary blunder-on more boldl •
• gainst the drawne sword in the Angels hand; to make his foot stand more firme in the path of the destroyer for a time, and to make him slide and fall in due time, and rise no more: This I knew to be the generall intendment of the booke before I saw it; yet I did desire to peruse it better, and for that purpose it was sent unto me.

p.hi: Have you read the Doctor so quickly, that you can give judgement of him?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No indeed, not as you call a reading, but I have read him as serves my purpose.

p.hi: I pray you what are your thoughts of him?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I doe not use to tell my thoughts, till I have well formed, and then weighed them, that I may speake not what I thinke, but what I know: I know he contends against God and Religion, with as much for •• ead (i. e. impudent boldnesse) as a righteous people contend for God and his cause with trembling and godly feare: Quae pro Religione cum grandi metu &c. p. 19 It is Salvians note of difference betwixt a godly and a wicked man, and it is notable.

p.hi: How come you to know this, and yet have not read the booke?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Ile answer you for that: I looked upon the FACE (that tells you what is at the heart) of his Book, and then upon the T • tle; an homely word, but it is the name the Lord gives its Author; Isa. 9.15. The Prophet that teacheth lyes, he is the taile; he speakes lyes, and makes the King glad with them, therefore he is the Taile.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You speake by a figure sure, and that I understand not; I told you at first you must be plaine, you must stoop to me; I must feele your words as a blinde man feeles your hand in the darke; for (walking in ignorance) in the dark I am.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Its well you know so much of your ignorance; if it be not knowledge it is the first step to it, To know how ignorant you are, and then to seeke knowledge as treasure is sought after: I would t ••• Doctor knew so much. But to answer your request, and that wee may stoop one to another, and feele each others words, I shall tell you now, That my manner is in reading to fixe upon the Title or Front of a Booke, and well to consider that first; for it is granted, that every Authour does,Semper respiciendum est ad Titulum. Plin. Ep. in compiling his booke, keep a due respect alwayes to his Title: Then turning from that very quickly, (as you will doe from that your soule loatheth) I fixed upon the close of the booke, the very last page, for there you will finde the sting,
• yes the Orator, (Pungit Orator and Poeta too) The Authour is smart and quicke in the close, if any where. Now I will tell you what I finde in both these pages, and require your judgment concerning the same.

In the Front, thus impudent he is, for thus he saies in effect, and would have us believe (and then he may goe on smoothly) That Dogges and Swine, (they are not his words, nor does hee allow of them; nor are they our words, they are the words of the Lord Christ, and then no matter for mans allowance) That Dogges and Swine (if there be any in Ireland or England; for he makes a question) doe onely pretend an offence (marke the word) Prete • d an offence, in shew only and semblance (tha'ts implied in the Title:) but in reality and truth these Dogges and Swine intend the defence of their Soveraignes Power and Rights, the established Religion &c. This you have in the very close of his booke; Hee has a word more, and then a short prayer, with which we can close very heartily, and say as he does,You shall have a further reply to his words, and heare more of his prayer, that it is a curse. Amen. Your judgement now upon two questions, and so you shall answere his booke as much as needeth, and as God commands us.

1. Doe you thinke that Dogges and Swine pretend onely to offend; pretend onely to rent and to teare; pretend onely to trample the Pearle under feet: doe these good-fellowes make a shew and semblance onely; pretend an offence to the King and Kingdome, but intend truly and indeed To defend the Person and the Pearle: what think you could you think so?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes indeed could I if I could thinke that the Divel and his Servants did but pretend to offend Job, they did intend to defend Persons, and houses, and cattell, and all: Or if I could thinke that Noahs floud was sent from heaven and the deeps below, to lay the dust onely, and not as a plague to punish the wickednesse of men upon earth.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
You have satisfied the question very well, and I verily beleeve all the Christian world are satisfied too touching that matter, That
Dogges and Swine (these bruitish men) do • but petend a defenc • , they intend an offence, robbing, spoiling, murthering, destroying all places and persons whereto their rage can reach; and to trample under the Pearle: This is an offence you thinke, and so thinks every sober man, except onely one man in sight (but he is not sober) Doctor Ferne. One question more, and your answer thereunto; which that you may give feelingly, I will make a supposition first, and then propose a question. I will make it your owne case; for indeed God may make it your case you know not how soon: Suppose that these Dogges and Swine were entring your house, ready to teare you to pieces, and were laying their bloudy hands upon all your Treasure there; Doe but suppose it so, the question is, Would you pretend a defence now, or would you intend your defence really and indeed to the utmost of your power? Pray you answere me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Indeed you doe not well to question a poore simple man so: I am simple indeed, yet 〈◊〉 so very a foole as not to intend my defence against Dogges and Swine.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Doe not take it ill I pray you, I intend your information in as sensible a way as I can imagine; and doe assure you that our betters, the Parliament, Nobles, and worthies there are accounted such fooles; for dogges are • lying at their face, and swine are trampling upon their Jewell, their Pearle; (I call it theirs, because they owne it, and doe account of it as of a Pearle) Swine are trampling upon this Pearle, and yet our Nobles and Worthies are said To take up Armes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That is true, all the reason in the world to take up Armes against Swine and Dogges: I shall never thinke is reasonable to use supplications to those beasts.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Let me goe on▪ They are not allowed to take up Armes against Swine and Dogges, for all power is in the Kings hand, he commands three kingdoms alone; and as he commands and refuseth, so it must be; and h •
•• fuseth to grant a Commission unto his Parliament To array the Kingdome.

p.hi: They h •• e power enough to grant themselves a Commission, and to seale unto it when they have done, have they not?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
It is too late to question it now; they have taken up Armes, and they are deeply charged for so doing by
• e • ne (I will not call a Teacher of lyes Doctor any more) with two the most horrid crimes, Rebelli ••
and Blasphemy: The former crime is (I suppose) disfused through the body of his booke, but the sting is in the Taile▪ the later is in the second lea • e, where he belcheth forth this vomit, The taking up of Armes by the Parliament, I doubt not to call a blaspheming of God and the King. I shall now conclude clean against him in these
Propositions, (1) That the Parliament have taken up Arms against Swine and Dogges: (2) That they are Swine and Dogges vvho have charged the Parliament with rebellion for so doing: (3) And that the charge of blasphemy upon them, is indeed a Blaspheming of God and the King. As sure as (by the patience of God) I now breath in this aire▪ so sure am I able to cleare all this even to the eye of the Christian world; and then the whole frame and structure of Fernes booke is destroied.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I pray you put-out your ability here, and make good your undertakings.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I shall doe it, though not in that order I have proposed, for that were to alter the frame of my discourse also,Not continued but dissolved into a Dialogue, that the phansic might have more scope to work upon the understanding. which was begun and proceeded-in to this very place, before I heard of the Doctors Reply. The former of these Propositions is cleared alreadie, yet more light I shall give unto it, though it be to hold-up a candle to the Sun: The other two will fall-in collaterallie, and by necessarie deduction, so as you shall say your understanding is fully cleared touching the same. I proceed now in my proposed method. I was saying, that the Parliament taking-up Armes without leave (against Swine and Dogges) are charged with Rebellion and blasphemy. And now here is a new charge, They are blasphemed as much on the other hand: Rebels before are hypocrites now, for they have taken up Armes in a pretended defence of Religion and liberty.

p.hi: A pretended defence! who sayes so I pray you?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That seductor, Doctor Ferne, in the forehead of his book.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Then be is all forehead, as I think your phrase is, he is an impudent man, past shame and grace both, I thinke, what thinke you?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I think the same which all sober men in the world will say of him now, looking on the Face and Taile of his booke; That hee is a notorious Foole, or a Knave; most likely-they will say hee is both.

p.hi: Is not that too bitter and harsh a censure?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No, it is not a censure; he is the verie mouth of Satan, that old Adversarie; he has dealt worse with the Parliament in point of slander and reproach then the Devil dealt with Job, Therefore he is like to heare worse anon; in the meane time this may serve to tell the world what he is, a notorious foole to thinke That the Parliament doe but pr • tend a defence against Dogges flying in their faces; and against Svvine trampling upon their Jewell; he is a notable foole for saying so.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
The Doctor is no foole sure, but I am confident he does not speake as he thinkes, not write as he meanes; he does not thinke that the Parliament have taken up Armes in a pretended defence of Religion and Liberties; the
Doctor is not such a foole to thinke so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Then he is a notorious Knave in print, to publish one thing to the whole world in such letters, which he who runs may read it, and to thinke cleane contrarie; everie sober man will account him a notable Knave for that, and so let him passe with an answer, according to his folly; for what-ever he expects hee deserves no other: Surely he has been brayed sufficiently, but a foole and his folly are inseparable. Besides, I verily beleeve he that will peruse the top of his booke and the bottome, will not trouble himselfe farther to enquire what is in the middle: So we will shut up his booke for the present.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But where are we? here is a digression sure, as you Schollers use to call it. Truly I know not where I am, I pray you set me in me in my way again.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I doe not thinke I have digressed: You remember your question was, Whether lawfull to maintaine Religion by the sword? It was argued, That it is lawfull in some case to contend with the sword; and if in any case, then in our case, to contend for a Pearle: Not with the sword said you, but with prayers: with a sword said I, and not with Prayers, because we are to contend with Dogs and Swine; there your understanding was cleared (as fully as I could in a little roomth) touching them, and that it was as vaine to contend against them with praiers, as to contend against a Beare with an Oatenstraw: At the verie point of time Fernes Answere (I am resolved for just reason never to call him Doctor any more) came to my hand, which told us as aforesaid, and in the fourth page assureth us, that 'tis blasphemie, To maintaine any defence at all about the pearle, for that the King and his partie are fully resolved to defend it (that is) To maintain Religion in its purity. This shall be fully enquired into and resolved anon; for the present, I have shewed you the face of this answere, and the sting in its taile: You resolved me two questions about it, and so wee cast it away for that time, as an accursed thing, not regarding what is in the middle: And so we returne whence we digressed, that we may conclude it lawfull To defend Religion with the sword. And let us take notice in passage, how tender the servants of the Lord have been in everie thing that has concerned the pearle, Religion, the service of their God; or has had any respect that way: and great reason the servants of the Lord should bee so tender and cautious in that point, because their Lord has reproved Kings for their sakes. 'Tis worthie all observation, That a zealous Priest once would not suffer a Censer to be touched with unwashed hands, yet they were the hands of a King: The Priest dealt roundly with the King, and roughly too, hee withstood him saies the Text,2 Chro. 26.18 and thrust him out of the Temple, and the King of Kings sets, as a speciall
note of dishonour upon the fore-head of the King: So a special note of honour upon the head of the Priest, lifting-him-up above his fellowes;1 Chron. 6.10. Azariab is he that executed the Priests Office in the Temple. What did the Priest doe there? As you heard, he withstood the King, hee would not suffer him to pollute the Censer; And this is his Testimoniall to the worlds end: And Azariab executed the Priests Office. And is there but a Censer polluted now? Surely more then a Censer is polluted now; Nay, in designe to bee taken away; a more precious thing then a Censer a Pearle: The Holy Holy Holy things of Christ, and His Spouse are polluted now; The Eternall Gospel is upon designe to be destroyed now; all the Lawes and Rights of Heaven and Earth are set under foot now. Surely, That man, whether high or low, Noble-man, Knight, Gentleman or poore man, what ever he be, That stands eminently-out now with his Sword in his hand for the maintenance of the cause in defence of the Pearle. He is the man, whom God takes speciall notice of▪ as he did of Azarian; This M •• executes his Office in the Kingdome which God has commended to 〈◊〉 care.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Forbeare a little, while I tell you what Doctor Ferne saith, That the Pearle (Religion) is more deare and precious to the King and his Party, than it is to the Parliament and their party, and the Primate of Ireland, as I beare, is of that mind too.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Jer. 8.9.For the first Man he is not worth the naming, he has rejected the word of the Lord, and what wisdome is in him? For the other, this is the least that can be said of him, this is he, that has not executed his office in the Temple; He has seen a more sacred thing than the Censer handled with unwashed hands, and yet he held his peace. The Lord lay it not unto his charge: or rather. The Lord charge it upon his Soul in Mercy unto his Soule, Amen. You shall have further satisfaction to what your Fe • ne saies▪ in due place.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I am Conscienously scrupled here, as some few others are, and as hee is who was before your Committees two daies agoe. We are ign •••• t. I co •
fesse, not knowing the Scriptures; But it is grievous to us to walke in the 〈◊〉 , • nd glad we would be to see our way cleare before us: We are cleerely resolved that the King is in a wrong way; his foot stands covered over with blood in the path of the destroyer, that is cleare unto us, and it is as cleare to our Consciences (yet, till you can resolve as the • ontrary from Scripture, and cleare two Scriptures to us) That all, who beare Armes against the King are Rebells all.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly I thinke so too; Nay I know it to be so; All that beare Armes against the King are Rebells, all; but we beare Arms for the King, and the Parliament, therefore we are good Subjects all

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
A Riddle to me! I shall never read it: The King protesteth▪
That he fights for the King of Heaven, and for all the Rights, Liberties and Priviledges of His Parliament on Earth (I mean His Church) Yee say the very same thing; Yee are for the King, yee say; The King is for you, hee sayes: In the meane time your Swords stand pointed one against the other. There is the Riddle; The Lord read it unto you, make it plaine to all the Christian World, and resolve your Soules in Rebeckahs question; why are wee thus?
Gen. 25.22. why is there such a struggling within the Bowels and Wombe of the Kingdom? all for the King and Parliament in words: the greatest number against King and Parliament in deed; Why are we thus? I pray you enquire heartily of the Lord touching this Matter.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I thanke you heartily for this Counsell, and to reply in a word, we have enquired of the Lord touching this matter, and wee have our answer; That our Lord and King is very angry; we▪ His People have grieved him to the very heart; Nay, wee have broken his heart; (it is His own expression) and hee has not spared, Hee has broken us with breach upon breach, for mighty Reasons, the one is in sight; we regarded not the works of God nor the operation of His hand; Psal. 2 • . The Lord (seemes) now to destroy His people, and not build them up; but not for any wrong wee have done against his King upon Earth, our very thoughts are pure touching that matter, so are our prayers: To his King on earth, we have done none hurt, no wrong at all. but all the right that could bee. The Lord is witnesse, the Lord God of Gods is wi • nesse, even he▪ That to His King •
• earth we have done none hurt, no wrong at all. This is our appeale, the Lord is judge, he will give answer in his owne time, we wait.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I must now intreat your trouble so far, as to enter-in, and lead me forth of this Maze. I my selfe, and others of my mind, are cleare at this point, and take it for granted, which Dr. Fe • ne calls a blaspheming of God and the King. That the King is seduced to a subversion of Religion and lawes; we make no (If) there, his actions have resolved us, and made all legible, and you have promised • o make that matter more cleare. Your maine work is now to cleare your selves in point of Rebellion, deeply charged upon you by Dr. Fern: what Scriptures hee has to beare out his charge. I know not, I believe, by that you have told me out of him, hee is slenderly read in the booke of God: but yet I am of his mind, till I have cleare resolution from you touching two Scriptures. The first will tell you, I thinke, that you have rebelled against the King. The second will assure you. The primitive Christians did not resist. The first Scripture which I believe will hold you a while, i • , And Israel rebelled against the house of David unto this day. I take it, you will read your selves Rebels there;2 Chro. • 0.19. They Rebelled saies the Text.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You desire only the exposition of these words, Rebelled, and Against.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, The words are cleere, Rebelled is rebelled, and Against is against, very plaine English, it needs no comment; I desire to know how you will quit your selves of Rebellion charged upon you in that Text.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Very easily and well, but your patience I pray you, while we read the Context; The summe of what that containes is this; That Rehoboam, a foolish King, who should have come to his people in the Spirit of meeknesse, came unto them with a Rod in his hand, shewes them the Rod first, flourisheth it in all the peoples sight; then speakes to the people as out of a whrilwind, storm-like, he assureth them, That the Rod they now see in his hand, shall be turned into a Scorpion shortly. When Israel saw the Rod, and heard of Scorpion, they, fairly shew their King their backs, and went every man to their Tents▪ Israel would not endure to bee whipped with Scorpions, and by their Kings hand, Psal. 72.2. who stood charged by his Grand-father, To break in pieces the oppressor: To judge GODS people with righteousnesse; and his poore with Iudgement: So they rent themselves from their Lord and King, and went their way.

p.hi: Read on, and read the last verse of the Chapter.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I will: And Israel slipt themselves fron under Rehoboams hand: They with-drew their necks from under his grievous yoke

p.hi: Indeed you read false.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly, I doe not.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You doe, for you should read thus, and Israel REBELLED.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
So it pleased the Translatour (and the sacred tongue is quicke and short) but in propriety of speech▪ and in the judgement of the Learned, it implies but as was said; And had it pleased the Translator, he had said as well, and as properly, if he had translated it, and Israel revolted, 2 Chron. 22.10. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
for so Libnah a City of Priests did; they revolted from their King; the word is the same, and has the same poin •
• n the right hand; and to their eternall honour it is spoken, in the judgement, of the best learned, That in so revolting; they did well, and that they did their duty: I shall make clearer proofe anon; They left their King when hee left God; let him rebell, They would not, their King should not Compell them: And yet they rebelled against their King, if you will have it translated as it is in your text, for the word is the same. we are charged to give the fairest and softest interpretation of Israels doings; I will deale so friend-like with Ferne, I could make cleare proof, that he has prevaricated in the great and high businesse of the Lord Jesus Christ, I say, prevaricated: he has made doublings, turnings and windings in a plain path, after the methods of the crooked Serpent▪ he has perverted the holy wayes of God; he has prevaricated;
you would not take it well now, if I should speake what I know, that hee has Rebelled against God, and the King. And yet the word implies so much; for it is the same word you have in the Text, yet I give the word a softer interpretation: I say that Ferne has prevaricated, and no more, though as a Man in the darke, and that has sold himselfe to doe wickedly, he has done infinitely more▪ he has rebelled once, and again, and now the third time, and means to rebell, for ought appeares to the contrary by his Scribble, till he be sent to his owne place. But novv I knovv no sober man, vvho holds That Israel, renting from the house of David, rebelled against Davids God. If the Adversary cannot prove it to bee a rebellion against God, wee are carelesse what he saies touching the Rebellion against man: If the parting from the King, when his foot stands in the path of the destroyer, bee in obedience to Davids God, according to his secret and revealed will, we will not trouble our selves, though it be reckoned by the Rebellious, a rebellious walking against the house of David: But grant at the last (vvhich vvill never be granted) That Israel rebelled, yet vve must remember this, That which may be called Rebellion in them, may bee pure obedience in us. There is as wide a difference betwixt vvhat Israel did then, and vvhat vve do novv, as there is a latitude in the power of the Kings of Is • ael then, and the Kings of England now. The Kings of Israel vvere more absolute Kings, then are the Kings of England, they ruled mostly by their Prerogative Royall (i. e.) by meere power. Our Kings ought to rule by the knovvn Lavvs of the Land. VVe have these Lawes to vvarrant our proceedings, Israel not so to vvarrant their revolt▪ The Lavv of nature pleaded for them, and vvhat more I cannot quickly tell my self; but it is very notable which wee read,2 Chron. 11.4. The Cause was of God: Indeed the Lord takes the matter upon himselfe, saying; This is done of me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You have explained the first word, say somthing to the other, for that is necessary, because for and against, these two words, have raised the greatest Question, that ever we heard of in the world untill this day.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is a great Question indeed, but fully cleared, and easily resolved. Therefore, touching that other word (against) I have but a word to say more; If ever any Parliament since there was a Parliament in England, did contend for their King, and against the Kings Adversaries, this is the Parliament: I could abundantly cleare this, had I time and space: Nay, it is cleared to every sober man, and for mad men no matter; The witnesse is in Heaven; to Him His servants have appealed; The Lord God of Gods is their witnesse here, and it is enough; though the Adversary writes bookes against them, no matter, their Record is on high.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My memory is short, helpe it I pray you, and recollect into a short sla • what was last said.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You may now gather-up all that has been▪ said touching this Scripture into two lines: (1) That your Scripture makes no more proofe, That all Israel rebelled, then that Libnab rebelled: But most cleare it is to him that will see, that Libnah did their dutie in revolting from him, who rebelled against God. (2) Grant that Israel rebelled, it does not follow that we rebell; for we walke orderly according to our knowne Lawes, and the King goes cleare against them; We wage warre in defence of the King and Kingdome, the King wageth a warre which is most contrarie to himselfe, and destructive to his kingdome.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You have considered me hitherto, a poore ignorant creature, who cannot distinguish betwixt the right hand and the left, in the things of God: and know no more, but that I am ignorant, and therefore cannot discerne the things that differ; I pray you (Sir) cannot you give me a rule from those Scriptures you have touched upon (concerning Israel and Libnahs revolt) whereby I may be able infallibly t • judge of Rebellion, so banded to and fro; no body will owne Rebellion, and never were there so many Rebels in the world.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
It is verie true: I read of a people of whom it is written, That their actions proclaimed them fooles to all the world, but they could not endure to be called fooles. A spade will endure to be called a spade; but no such Traitour as he, who is so, but will not endure to bee called so: nor any such Liar in the vvorld as is he, who will give you the stab if you give him the lie. It is so at this time, There are a people up in Armes against God and the King, but they will not endure to be called Rebels: Let that passe for the present, wee will finde them out anon, and call them Rebels too. I like your motion well, surely I will endevour to cleare your judgement touching Rebellion, How you may judge of a rebellion against Davids house; briefly thus: Observe narrowly vvith all your eies (you have more then two) whether you see men bearing-up stoutly against God, contending with him as if they had an arme like God, treading-downe His hedges, breaking-over His bounds, casting away His cords, saying in effect, The Lord Christ shall not be Lord over us: Doe we heare and see these things? doe we heare men speak blasphemies? doe we see men offering violences to all the lawes of heaven and earth? doe we see this, or doe we not? It must needs be answered, We doe see it: Then we doe see the clearest Rebellion against the house of David: But when I see nothing which I can call a Rebellion against God, no not any thing done that has any appearance that way. [For to sence my throat against Murtherers; to safeguard
my house against Robbers; to flye from the rod in a mans hand, (for his mercies are cruelty) specially when he shall threaten to sting me with a scorpion; to maintaine the pearle also, and to pluck it from under the feet of Swine; none of all this has any shew or appearance of Rebellion against God, none at all:] And if not against God, then I must not dare to censure it a Rebellion against Davids house; for certainly it cannot be a rebellion against Davids house, but it must be against God first.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I pray you cleare this in the two cases before, and then in our case.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I am about it, to cleare this question here so stiffely controverted in the world, and to shew forth Rebellion in its scarlet colour, I will, according to your desire instance in the case of Israels people, and then of Israels Priests, and afterwards make our own case verie legible in theirs.

In the first case, What have we in sight? A rod flourishing before the peoples eies, and Scorpions threatned, heavie yokes prepared for the necks of Israel, and a little finger menaced to presse and set-on upon the peoples shoulders heavier then the loines of a man; this was in sight on the Princes part, who wanted understanding, therefore was he also a great oppressor;
Pro. 28.16. and all this cleare against the command of God, Thou shalt not oppresse (no not) a stranger, much lesse thy brother; nay, if thou seest an oppressor of Gods people, Thou shalt breake him to pieces, that is the charge. What does Israel doe now? They see the yoke is like to pinch, and they slip their neckes out of it, and away they went.

p.hi: Then they rebelled.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No.

p.hi: God sayes they did.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You can never prove that.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: His word sayes they did.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It does not.

p.hi: The interpreter renders it so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But without the booke, for that Word will not prove them Rebels against God.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Take the softest interpretation, it proves that they revolted from their King; And if no more at that time, yet tis cleare to all the world, they rebelled against God▪ presently after.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Now you say something, but you can never make it good, That Israel rebelled against God: the context is cleare, that not one (True) Israelite, (that set his heart to seeke the Lord) not one true Israelite that would rebell against God; they were,2 Chro. 11.26 as they ought to be, exceeding tender at that point: For when they saw what way Ieroboam went in, a way of Rebellion against his God, presently
they left him, and hastened to Jerusalem, there to worship God as he commanded. I pray observe the Chapter, you will finde everie (True) Israelite fully resolved against Idolatrie, serving of God after their owne inventions; and this will evidence them to be faithfull to God, and then you can never prove that they rebelled against the house of David. Their Kings Idolatries and his oppressions, these are in sight, and great Rebellions against God: In the people you observe no more, but, that they were affrighted at the sight of the rod, and hearing of the Scorpions, and so went their way. It is true, here was a judgment which God inflicted upon Reboboam the King, and Israel his people, for the sins of both, no question to be made of that; and there is the first case.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Let me heare the other explained concerning Israels Priests; I hope I may the better judge of rebellion, when I see their cases both together.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Indeed if their actions will beare it, the word will: for, as I told you, it is the same in your Text, they Rebelled, though the Interpreter was more considerate and cautious here: for the resolving hereof,2 Chron. 21. and making cleare to you, What it is to rebell, it is necessary to enforme you what their King Jehoram was, and what the Priests did. First, and in two words, their King was a Barrabas, a notable murtherer, and an abominable Idolater; such a King he was, and the reason is given, he had the daughter of Ahab to wife; a woman of a masculine spirit, what she had a will to doe she did, like a Tyrant.

p.hi: Was not her husband King?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes, but she was Empresse; he wore the Crowne, but shee swayed it; he had the name, but she ruled: there was no use of a King, but onely of his hand and seale; the Queen decreed unrighteous decrees, and prescribed grievousnesse, and the King sealed unto them: And then the King made high places; [you must not thinke he hoisted-them-up with his owne hand, no more then he did with his owne hands kill his brethren; Commissions were sealed, and sent to his servants to that purpose;] and (by prescribing grievousnesse) he caused Jerusalem to commit fornications, 2 Chro. 21.11 and compelled Iudab (marke that.) And now you have heard what the King was, and what he did, and who were his Counsellours.

p.hi: What did the Priests?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: As their King did, all that were vile and treacherous, they willingly followed the commandement.

p.hi: But what did Libnah doe (as you said) a City of Priests, what did they doe?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: They Revolted, in that place; They Rebelled, in yours, as the Translatour renders it; and indeed some doe say plainly, Libnah rebelled to th • s day: So did the Scots foure yeares agoe; so doe we now.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That was my request, That you would inform me, give me a RULE whereby to judge of this crime.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I have given it you already, Ile repeat it againe; spy-out here (and yet you need not looke so narrowly) is there any Rebellion in sight here against God?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes sure, in sight a great deale; for here are horrible murthers, abominable Idolatries: and here the Crowne is laid in the Queenes lap, who was daughter of Ahab; and a Commission sealed to compell Iudah to doe as the King and Queen did.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You observe it very well; and that the King walked most rebelliously against his God. But have you observed any Rebellion in the Priests?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, there is a word implyes so much, They revolted, which my Transtatour renders, They rebelled.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Well, but remember your Rule, and enquire, did they rebell against God?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No indeed, I finde not a syllable that tends that way.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Then you may be cleare in point of Rebellion; If no Rebellion against God, none at all, but all in obedience to God, and his command, then no rebellion against Davids house, I meane against Iehoram their King: Tell me (for you shall be Judge) whether is fittest, To obey God, or the King?

p.hi: It is fittest to obey both.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Very true, if both can be obeied; but if their commands stand at such a distance, as doe stand the two Poles, North and South;2 Chro. 6.16. the Temple of God and Idols, how then, whom will you obey now?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
The King of Kings sure, and Lord of Lords; I must obey him,
Acts 7. it is a resolved case.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It was the Priests case. (2) Consider, Gods command draws one way, the Kings hales another vvay, vvhich vvay vvill you take?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The way of the upright sure, for that is a lightsome path, the path of Gods commandements.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It was the Priests case. (3.) The King forsakes God, God forsakes him, then he blundered-on in the darke path, where was no light, would you blunder after him?

p.hi: No, for then I must have fallen▪ and have beene in danger never to have risen againe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I say the third time, It was the Priests case, and the Spirit expresseth it so; And Libnah revolted from under their Kings hand: 2 Chro. 21.10 Why did they so? Because he had forsaken the Lord God of his Fathers. Can you judge of Rebellion now? are you cleare at that point?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Truely I am, it is most cleare as is the Sun in the firmament, that the
King rebelled against God; and the Priests, in pure obedience to God, revolted from him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Tell me one thing more; could you be content to be called as the good Priests were called, (nay, are called) rebels against their King? could you bee content to bee as they, and in their case, so reproved, would you be content?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Content! Yes indeed could I, and more, I could count it my glory; my glory and Crown of rejoycing, to be accounted a Rebell against my King; a Revolter from him, while in Gods account, I am his faithfull and obedient servant. It is the greatest honour unto Priests and people, To be Rebels and Traitors in the Kings account, and the greatest dishonour to be right men for his service, pressed Souldiers for his warfare, so long as he Warres against God, and the House of David.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: VVell said, it is your case, for it is the very case of all Gods faithfull Servants in the world; and this case comes now to bee considered; for we cannot forget our own case.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I thank • you heartily, That you will resolve me here also; Truly I long for resolution, that I may satisfie my own Conscience, and give righteous Iudgment touching Rebellion in our case. My Iudgment is cleared in the other Cases, but I cannot conceive (it is my ignorance perhaps) how you can make our case so cleare, being so different in my apprehension, to both the former Cases: This was Israels Case, They revolted, slipt their necks out of the Collers, as you say, and went their way. They shewed their King the Heele, they did not kick with the beele; they did fly from the rod and the Scorpion, they did not contend with their King, to pluck the rod out of his hand. And for Libnah, they revolted from their King; so we read, and no more; we do not read of any Sword held-up against their King. Tell me I pray you, how to judge of Rebellion in our Case, and on whose side it is, for Swords are lifted-up on both sides.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
The Resolution hereunto depends very much upon the resolving you touching that you last spake; You see no violence done by Israel, nor no Swords in the Priests hands: You see violence done by us you thinke, and Swords in our hands; Therefore if it should be denied, That Israel or the Priests were Rebellious: yet will it be affirmed, That wee are Rebels. But see how you are mistaken! our Case exceeds both theirs in sight: First, Rehoboam shewes the people the rod, and threatens the Scorpions; King Charles (for I will speake out) makes his people feele the Scorpions; and his little finger heavier than his fathers loines. His people resist now; whom? They call God to record, They resist the Scorpions, not the King: and notwithstanding all this, they doe not rent themselves, nor depart away from the King: but he rents himselfe from his Parliament, he
departs away from himselfe, and his good people: Yes, and we must adde, though it is a sad addition, he is departed from God too; The Lord knows how farre (departed) from God, and from all the laws of heaven and earth.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You have said, and I doubt not but you know what you say, but let me tell you what Doctor Ferne saies touching this matter; this; That ye are desperately fallen from God and the King; but the King keeps close unto God; you fight against your King for a Religion you freely enjoy, out of a feare, and jealously only of a change: And as for your Army, Besides some Troopes of Forreigners, and Papists, and some bands of unwilling Prest men, It has its chiefe strength from the prevalency of such Sects, as are condemned by the laws of the Land; and so he concludes very gravely and graciously (out of the Booke he takes his Sermon) with these words; A Frantick Religion needs such furious maintenances, as is rebellion.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Indeed you doe not well to quote Ferne, a stigmatized fellow, noted with his own hands, upon his fore-head for a Foole and a Knave both, and it shall be cleared anon, That he is the mouth of the Divel too, and can any sober man regard what that mouth speakes, or be carefull to make answer thereunto? Yet he may have a returne of his words in due place, and the doubt cleared (though none but Swinish men make doubt of it) who doe fight for the King, and for Religion, and who against both; and on whose side these Papists are. Now you expect I should say somthing to the other Case of Israels Priests: It is true, we read nothing of a Sword there; The Priests revolted, and no more; and the King was so wise, as not to send the Sword after them, to Compell them to blaspheme; but had the heads of the Tribes been associated, and sitting in Parliament about this matter; whether the King had power to Compell his people as aforesaid: And had their King deserted his Parliament; and taken to him 20000. men, under preten • e of a Guard, but with a full intent to fall upon the heads of Israel; And to reduce Libnah, to his and his Queenes obedience; had it beene so, what would have been done then, I cannot tell my selfe▪ but I believe, then there had bin Swords drawing on both sides, I • shua 22. Iudgdes 19. as well as in Ioshuas time, and in the dayes of the Judges; But this was not Israels case, then, tis ours now. And now I hope I shall be able to resolve your Conscience, and cleare your understanding, so as you shall bee able to judge on whose side Rebellion is▪ (That is) you shall clearely
• s • e, beare and understand, who are Swine and Dogs; who trample upon the Pearle; who blaspheme God and the King: I cannot doubt but to give the clearest satisfaction here, that can bee desired, because you shall have all the helps, that are desirable, for the clearing your understanding at this point; you shall call up all your fi • e wits (your
Senses I meane) every one shall give-in their evidence, to the Truth then you shall unite all five into one faculty, so as you shall clearly see and understand, what you doe.
