And because we resolve to be serious, and to speake as the Oracles of God, That the simple Reader may trust us and believe our report: I charge you before the living God, to answer the truth now, and nothing but the Truth, as you have heard, seene, and understood; So I begin in order, with that excellent Organ of knowledge, your eare, what heare you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Blasphemies from one side, I am sure, for I heare Protestations from both, all for God, and to maintaine Religion.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You see now, you have need of your other sences, for you cannot judge by the hearing of your eare: what doe you read?

p.hi: Proclamations, Declarations, Commissions, and an Act of pacification with the Irish — and English—

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Speake out man.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I want a word whereby to expresse those execrable —

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What doe you see?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Laws, Rights and Liberties of the Subject, trampled under foot; I see Cities impoverished, Townes wasted, Villages fired, Males murthered, Females ravished.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Is that all? You see somwhat more sure, you remember the Charge, to speake as in the eares of God; what more doe you see?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I see the Pearle trampled under foot also.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: By whom?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By Swine, for none other but Swinish men will trample upon a Pearle.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Then there be Swine in England: but what doe you smell; for I told you, you should use all your sences in this Case; what doe you smell?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Exhalat opaca mephytim. Truly the most hellish savour, the most loathsome stench, that ever was cast abroad in the world, worse then the stinke from a putrified Corpes; and it is the stinke of the Kings Campe, that comes up into our Nostrils. Every mans throat there, is like an open Sepulchre.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: How doe you Relish, what you heare, read and smell from the Kings side?

p.hi: As the gall of Aspes to my taste.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What doe you feele?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I can say little to that, for the murtherers never came within foure miles of my doores, but had I a sympathy (as you Schollers call it) of a member, had I a fellow feeling of what is felt, my words would be sighs, and you would see them pointed with teares: Truly, to tell how sadly these oppressions speake to the hearts of them, that are companions with those, who suffer; and how sorrowfully they speak,
who are under these oppressions, is impossible, for it is unspeakable.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Indeed you speake feelingly. Now call upon all your five wits together, and unite them into one faculty; then tell mee what you understand touching matters now a daies?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Truly I stand at a maze: Ah Lord! VVhat contrarieties in things! What contradictions in words! Confusions in deeds! What Blasphemies! What Murthers! What Villanies! What outrages of all sorts and sizes! What bloody — executions! And that you call the Pearle (Religion) how doe Swinish men trample upon it, as mire in the streets!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: VVhat observation make you of all this? Do you observe, That there are any Dogs and Swine in the Land?

p.hi: Yes, multitudes, and that they are Swine and Doggs, who affirme the contrary; and in so doing, doe blaspheme God and the King.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Then you do observe Rebellion in the Land against David and his house.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell what you meane by David and his House; what doe you meane by it (Sir?)

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: T • e King in heaven, and his King on earth, and his People, his House and Houshold there; doe you observe any Rebellion now against David and his house?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ah Lord! Observe any Rebellion, say you? I observe nothing else but Rebellions; Rebellion against the Lord God of Gods; Rebellions against the King of Saints; Rebellions against the Lord our King and Rebellions against the Lords Annointed.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You meane the King, doe you not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No indeed, though he is the Lords anointed; I meane the people of God, made Kings and Priests to God the Father; for such annointed people there was, upon the earth, before there were Kings there.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: VVell: who is the chiefest in this Rebellion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ah Lord! You have charged mee to speake as the Oracle of God, as in his eares The truth, according as all my Senses have reported to my understanding; and as my understanding has given in their evidence, and now I must answer — Ah Lord!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Be not afraid, man, let not the terror of a man make thee afraid; the Lord, not I, Hee chargeth thee to speake as the Oracle of God, and as in the eares of God, speake out man, what you are able to • ake good; It is for God and his cause, and to stop the mouth of the slanderer: You speak for the King, his Crowne and Dignity, and for his soul, that it may prosper at last▪ The breaches he has made upon his Crowne, will not be made up with flattering words; nor will the wounds in his soul, be healed with balm; nor can his bloodshed
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
be wiped-off vvith a soft cloth, no more then pitch can be wiped off with Wooll: Speake out what you know, who is the chiefe leader in this great trespasse against the Lord?

p.hi: Ah Lord! the King is chiefe in this rebellion against His Lord, David and his house.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Now looke to it, that you can shew your evidences, and make good proofe; for there are strong evidences against you, Remonstrances, and Manifest • 's, Declarations, and Protestations, all from the King to undeceive the people, and to give them confident assurance, That he Intends the advancing of Gods glory in the first place, The defence of Religi • n in the second place, The kingdomes Rights and the peoples liberties at the last. You understand all this, doe you not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes very well: I have heard, and seene, and read all this; and all this deceived the people a very little time, till the Kings hand declared it selfe cleane crosse to his tongue, and his deeds were Contra-Remonstrances to his words: I observe vvhat the Kings Actions have beene and are; what is done, not what is spoken: The glorie of God, and the honour of His Name, has been pretended, when the most in-glorious things have been intended and practised: And so now, the glorie of God was pretended, shewed forth to the eyes of the people, as a vaile cast-over the Kings hands, reached out unto the Antichrist, the Pope, and his Bishops, to helpe them in their warre against the Lambe: The King has chosen, if not (as Ieroboam did) Calves to be his gods, (for this is not so visible, if not so) yet hee has chosen such servants as Ieroboam did, Antichrists Servants now; Divels then (and no better now) to be his Priests;2 Chro. 11.15 he has entertained Irish-Priests, he has taken them into his bosome, bee has done all that was in the power of his hands to doe against the Lord Christ, and His hidden-ones, to helpe Antichrist and all his helpers.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But all this is for the defence of the true religion: so the King protesteth, and Ferne sayes as much, and more.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I have said already, It is of small weight vvhat the King protesteth, and lesse what Ferne affirmeth: The King protesteth the defence of the true Religion; An horrible blasphemie! for who are his defendors? whom takes he to him for to defend Religion? None other but Atheisticall Ruffians, notable murtherers, abominable idolaters; likely men to defend Religion! And what Religion is practised by these defenders? but what was practised in Queen Maries daies, Queene Maries religion; and so the servants of the • ord, the true professors of religion are persecuted now, as in Queen Maries daies, yet the King maintaines the true religion! I say again, an horrible blasphemie, such as was never heard from the beginning upward untill this day, That the King intends to maintaine the
glorie of God, to defend Religion, when he puts forth his hand, according to the power in his hand, to dethrone the Lord Christ, King of Sain •• ; To trample upon the Pearle, to take away the Gospel, the Crowne of his Crowne, and glorie of his land. Thus you have the summe of what the Senses have reported to the mind, and the result of that the minde has reported to the understanding, whereby to give righteous judgement.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You are (I perceive) willing to touch as lightly upon these matters, as you could: you have made no mention of those thousand thousand soules slaine in Ireland; but there are Declarations and Remonstrances enough touching that Tragedie, and who were the chiefe Actors therein: One act of Rebellion there is, little thought on, or not at all, but it must not be omitted, because I verily perswade my selfe it was the Source and head-spring from which all the Rebellion of King and people has issued ever since: In a true sense of duty, and zeale for the Kings prosperity, I will goe-up so high as is that head-spring from whence profanenesse is gone forth into all the land; The King commanded the profanation of the Lords day, you forget that.

p.hi: N • , I thought the Bishops were chiefe in that trespasse; and that you would roule that burden upon their heads anon.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
So I will, for they were right-men for such a purpose; I doubt not but they were his Counsellours, they advised him to make an experiment of his power, make his people know he was King, if so be his command could give checke and mate to Gods command, then he might rule over men, and doe what he listed. Doubt • esse the Bishops plotted and platted that Garland of May-games, and then perswaded their Lord and Master to crowne the Lords day with it: The greatest dishonour and mockerie that ever was offered to the Lord Christ, since the Crowne of Thornes was set upon His head: And as the King was counselled, so hee did more presumptuously then any • e • then King before him: For passe over the Isles of Chittim, and see; und send unto Kedar, and consider diligently,
Ier. 2.10, 11. and see if there be such a thing: Hath a nation changed their gods, which are no gods? [or the daies dedicated to the honour of those gods?] But a Christian King, and his people by his command, have changed their God, and His glorie: for what? for a thing of naught, lighter then vanitie, a morrice-dance for that which doth not profit indeed. Surely the Lord hath smitten His hand at this profanation, so exceeding; for in so doing the King did set his throne above Gods throne; he commanded against the command of God. Certainly his throne is shaken for this, and shall never stand steady and be established, till after his heart be shaken for it with godly sorrow: he has (he does) profane
the Rest of God, and has commanded so, doubtlesse he shall be restlesse till he be in the deeps for this, as well as for his Idolatry and bloud-shed. Here is now sufficient proofe, That the King is chiefe in Rebellion against God; what thinke you, vvho is chiefe in rebellion against himselfe, his owne Crowne and dignitie.

p.hi: It must needs be answered, himselfe; For if he be chiefe in Rebellion against God, he must needs be the chiefe Adversary against himselfe.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It's very true, but yet I would have you make it as plaine to your Readers understanding, as it is plaine to yours.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That I cleare thus: he has hearkened to evill Counsellours, and now he has wrested the Scepter out of his owne hand; he has strucke the Crowne from off his owne head • he has throwne downe his owne throne; he has set on fire Davids house, though he can have no other ben • fit by it, but to smother himselfe in the smoke. Ah Lord!

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Sad things indeed: cleare them I pray you yet more.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Scepter of this Kingdome also is a right Scepter, a Scepter of Righteousnesse: The King has throwne judgement and justice out of his hands; he threw away his Scepter, and strucke off his Crowne at the same time, and plucked away the supporters of his throne, the two pillars thereof.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Prov. 16.12.20.28 25.5 29.14 1 Kin. 7.21Indeed it is most true which you say, The throne is established in righteousnesse; it is said twice, nay three times, for the thing is certaine; judgement and justice are like the two pillars, Iachim and Boaz, salvation and strength to the King and kingdome. These are (to the throne) as were the stayes on either side Solomons throne, or the two Lions that stood besides the stayes, and like the twelve Lions which stood upon the ascent to the throne, all and everie whereof made for the glorie, peace, security, establishment of the throne; such supporters: And now that these are throwne out of the hand, and violence and oppression (to doe it) are in the hand in stead thereof; now the Scepter, the Crowne, the Throne, must all fall flat to the ground, for the Supporters are gone, Iudgement and Iustue. So now you are able to judge of a rebellion against Davids house, and to give cleare proofe, Who are chiefe in that trespasse: I need not put you to prove now,
••• v. 29 12 That all the Kings Servants are wicked, for the wisest of Kings has said that so it is, when the King himselfe hearkens unto lyes, and is made glad with them: Nor will I aske you, whether you observe any Rebellion against Davids house; all this is so clear to the eye, that I will not trouble you to say more about it: Onely I pray you let me know your judgement in that, wherein the eye is not commonly so cleared; Doe you thinke that there are no other rebells in the kingdome then they, who are the Kings Right-men, Irish — and English — helpers and promoters of this rebellion against Davids house; are there no more, thinke you?

p.hi: O yes, many more, and I am one of the number.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Very well, an ingenious confession! but you are not the more rebell because you say so: You meane (I suppose) that you have rebelled against God, you know not hovv often, and you find rebellions in your owne heart: Is it not so, and is not that your meaning?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes indeed, I have rebelled against God, and (in so doing) against Davids house, and the prosperity thereof, and I finde rebelli • ns in my owne heart s ••• l still.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Well I verily beleeve you; Rebellions are in you (you are not in a Rebellion;) you hate them, doe you not? you would master and subdue them, would you not?

p.hi: Yes indeed, it is my greatest desire, as strong as after the Lord Christ.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Well said indeed; though you put your selfe in, Ile put you out of the number of Rebells: Nay, God has separated you from that rout; take it upon my word he does not account you a Rebell; therefore goe, count againe, and exempt your selfe, and all like you: Doe your senses tell you that there any Rebels in the kingdome, yet professing themselves on Gods side, and for the house of David: These are rebels indeed; are there any such?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes many; I know not how many Rebels there are, yet professing themselves on the Parliaments side; The Parliament Souldiers are not all Saints.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You speake by a figure, you meane more then you speake; you meane, many of them are as bad as the English — and Irish — Doe you meane so?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No indeed, for I understand by all your discourse hitherto, and by the interpretation of Christs owne words, that men may be exceeding wicked, as true Devils as Herod was a Foxe, and yet not as are the Irish — and English — Dogs and Swine, they.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly you say right; but goe on and tell me what you meane when you say, that all in the Parliaments Armies are not all Saints.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I mea • e, there are Devils in the Parliaments Army, who have given too just cause unto the Adversarie, Doctor Ferne, to tell us, what is that Religion that the Parliament would by such meanes maintaine?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Fern shall have a sharp word anon, but tell him now when you meet vvith him▪ that there were but twelve choice men, chosen by Christ himselfe, and one of them was a Devill▪ There are twelve thousand Souldiers on the Parliaments side, Job 6.70 and suppose there be twelve hundred Devils there, yet this does cast no more dishonour upon the Parliament, that there are so many Divels in their Armies, then it did upon the Lord Christ that there vvas a Divell amongst the twelve: I shall anon prove Ferne himselfe to bee a Divell, and a
Swine (which is the worst Devill) yet shall it be no reproach to honest men, but a glory rather, that a Divell and a Swine is discovered; And here now, I must informe your selfe, that it had beene a rash Censure in those daies, to have reproached any of the Eleven, because one was a Devill; So, nor are you to reproach so much as our Armies, much lesse the Parliament, because there are so many Devils there; (though indeed, these are a reproach wherever they are) and much lesse must the wickednesse of a few, bee cast as a reproach upon a Parliament; you must consider with all Consideration, what the Parliament intends by their Armies on the Land, and Navy on the Seas, what Intend they by all this?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Dr. Ferne Answers you, and indeed it is an offence unto me, These intend to wrest the Scepter out of the Kings hands, the Crowne from his Head; To alter Religion; To overthrow the established frame of G • vernment.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Indeed you doe not deale fairly with me, when I entreat your answer, such as sense and reason dictate to you, and you answer me by Ferne, the mouth that speakes blasphemies, the mouth of the Divell (as you shall heare presently) yet to give you full satisfaction, I doe assure you, were Ferne as neere my elbow, as you are, I would undertake to convince him of blasphemy against God and the King, in the Judgment of every sober man; nay in his owne Judgement if he dares yeeld it up to the Judgment of God and the Scriptures, which he will never doe. And because he will not nor will he come at me, and I am resolved not to come to him; I will deale with your selfe, requiring of you to tell mee touching this reproach upon the Parliament; What you see, heare, and throughly understand: I dedemand of you then, what are the Actions of the Parliament?

p.hi: Alas they are too high for me to see into.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: They are not, you can see infinitly higher (to our finit capacity) you can see above the moone, above the Sun too; you can see as high as the highest Starre, you cannot tell how high you can see: Then you can see the actions of a Parliament; I demand 〈◊〉 the Parliament offered any violence to the Kings person?

p.hi: I heare they have, and from his owne Pen.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
You cannot tell that, but I pray you, when you are charged to speake your knowledge, as an Oracle, and as from the Oracle of God, doe not tell me what heare-say saies, a most notorious lyar: Tell me what you know; have they not made supplications to him three times, Nay, seven times? have they not petitioned him again and againe, and againe. To doe himselfe, and his people right, to build up his house, and Davids house the house of his Kingdom, To judge Gods people with righteousne • s, and his poore with judgment, have they not done so? They have, God is witnesse, and
their Consciences too, our eyes also. Have they not been as tender even of his Body, of his Soule much more, as of the Apple in their owne eye? They have, God is witnesse, and their Consciences too, our eyes also. Have they not gone backward, and backward again and again, and the third time, to hide their Kings nakednesse, which would not be hid? They have, God is witnesse, and their Consciences too, and our eyes also. Have they not sought all meanes to fix the Scepter in his hand; To fasten the Crowne on his head; to establish their King in his Throne, by maintaining Judgement and Justice, the Supporters and Pillars of all this; have they not done so? They have, God is witnesse, their Consciences too, our eyes also.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They have not bin tender of the Kings Prerogative.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: What is that? Too high indeed for you and I to talke of. But this I dare say, The Prerogative was never more talked of, nor never lesse understood: Never so strained as of late, therefore never so broken as now, which must needs bee, when there is not a meane betwixt the Kings Prerogative, and the Subjects Priviledges, to Soder them together. Queene Elizabeth spake little of her Prerogative; but never had any Prince a Prerogative at more length and more freedome. A blessed Prerogative, which is bounded within Gods limits: and accursed is that from Gods mouth, which will take power beyond Gods allowance, and exerciseth it against GODS Command; but this is above your understanding, perhaps; I will goe on in the exercise of your senses; what benefit have the Subjects found from the Parliaments Armies?

p.hi: Some of our friends have found very little benefit from some of the Parliament Souldiers, for they have beene plundered by them. Indeed some of the Parliament souldiers have committed strange insolencies, against the known Laws, Rights and Liberties of the Subject.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Indeed I am a little angry; you tell me what some have done, and what some have suffered. I have Answered that already. There are some Divels in the Parliaments Army, and they will doe like Divels: but my Question is touching a generall good; what benefit hath the Kingdome received from the Parliaments Armies?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Vnspeakable benefits; they have been as a wall about us by Sea, and by Land; by Seas they have shut up the doores and fronteirs of the Kingdome, that the beasts of prey might not breake-in: Indeed our eyes give cleare judgement in that matter. And had not that Thrice noble Generall (defamed for his faithfullnesse in guarding Davids house) had not this excellent Lord beene faithfull to God, the King, and the State; Then whereas a thousand beasts of prey have thrust-in, and as many instruments of Death, Ten thousand bad thrust-in upon us, as Beasts of Prey into a vineyard, that has
neither wall nor ditch, nor any such fence; and so (for the Land) to the eternall praise of that excellent Earle,
Iudg. 5.9. and of those Lords and Knights: [our hearts are towards the Governours of Israel that offered themselves willingly among the people: blesse yee the Lord] In Command and Commission with him; had not these discharged their Care, and faithfullnesse towards Davids house, Then had our Cities all been Ruinous heapes, our Townes and Villages had been made Church-yards, scarce large enough to Bury-in.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Very well, you doe see your owne preservation in all this, do you not?

p.hi: Yes indeed, though I ascribe all to Gods wing over mee: These Armes have been a means under God, To keep the VVolfe from my doores, The murtherers from entring my house.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You doe remember the 12. of November, that Saturday night, when the Wolves thought to prey upon the Sheepe in London; you remember that, and Gloucester too, doe you not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes indeed, I remember all this, and a great deale more.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: VVell, and you doe remember to draw forth your soule to the hungry, specially to those who are a guard about you and your house, night and day, you remember that. But now you see plainely the Actions of the Parliament in their Armies (for the Actions and scatterings, of particular men, are not to be put upon the Parliaments reckoning) are faire and specious, I might say, and glorious, for such they are, that have vexed the Adversary to the heart, made them storme like the Devill; Nay, they have stormed the Devill; and they have beene able to beare up against all his storming. But let me crave your judgment in one thing more; Do you thinke, that the Parliament in their Armies, doe but pretend the Defence of the Kingdome, their Rights, Priviledges, and Liberties there? VVhat thinke you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thinke! I know, That every sober Man, does heartily and indeed intend the defence of his Liberty: Then sure, that is the intent of the Parliaments Forces; They doe not pretend a defence of the Kingdomes, the defence of their owne Rights and Liberties there, and intend to fight themselves into slavery; no sober men will doe so, I am confident of that.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Indeed so you may bee, That no sober men will do so, And yet there are Nobles, Knights, and Gentlemen (they would bee accounted so) who contend with both hands,Nequitiae sordibu • imbuta N •
bilia po • tenti, V • l. Max. lib. 3. 5. tooth and naile, to make themselves slaves: But indeed, as you said well▪ these are not sober nor men neither in the Heathens account, but Monsters who will fight themselves into slaverie.

sp.speaker: A.
B.
sp.p:
Nothing; not a word will I answer to a man that curseth when he thinkes he prayes, (as you shall see Fernè has done) not a word to him, that goes against common principles: you remember the old Rule, Contra negante • principia non est disputandum: there is no arguing with a man who denies that there are any Dogs and Swine in the world, (for if there bee none in Ireland, nor England, there are none in the world:) no answer to him who denies, that Wolves are grievous to the Sheepe; and affirmes, that Sheepe are grievous to the Wolves: who denies, that fire will burne; That mad dogs will bite; That Scorpions will sting: we must say nothing to such mad fooles, who will contradict the verdict that all his outward senses, ears, eyes, &c. and all the inward faculties, Vnderstanding, Reason, Iudgement, have given-in unto him. What? has the King and his Armies made no invasion upon the Kingdomes Lawes, Rights, Liberties? Sensus falluntur inepte, as was said to one, who must not beleeve his eyes; Can mens estates and lives be taken from them, and more barbarously used then so, and yet not their Rights and Liberties invaded? This is like old Chaucers tale of a Fryar, whose belly was his god, he would feed upon the sweetest, Mutton, Goose, and
Pig, but a pitifull man! he would have no cre • ture killed for him not he. If Ferne had not beene as one of those dogs and swine, and scorpions, that have so rent, stung, and spoiled the Kingdome; nay, if he had not beene. I say not, as, but
•• e o • them for he more then lookes on the day of his brother;
Obad. 11.12. then had he told us, That the Kings Army i •••• d the taking away of the Kingdomes Liberties, and subjects B • r • h •• ght, for his hou • e had beene plundred before this, and more; but the Divell will not hurt his good servants, and Right-handed men in the world. And now I had done but that I must intreat you to observe with all observation, That Fernes words make clear answer to a grand and grave Question which is this▪ What is the Religion The King has so often and so solemnly pro • ested to maintaine? It is that Religion, which the Kings right-men, his Ministers, and Servants, Papists, Atheists, Robbers, Murtherers, Irish —and Engl h—monsters doe defend It is Fernes answer, if you observe his words; Now marke his Prayer, and you will observe, that the Spirit of God over ruled him as he did Balaam, who intended to blesse Moab, and to curse Israel: but he did contrary, hee cursed Moab, and blessed Israel; so this Balaam has done now; he intended to blesse the King, his Counsels at home, his designes abroad his Armies in Ireland and England▪ and himselfe with the rest, but he has cursed all these and all together, and not blessed them at all. For thus he prayes, The God of power and wisedome cast out all counsels, and defeat all designes, that are against the rest •
ring of our peace, and the continuance of the true Reformed Religion. We will joyne with them in the Close saying, Amen, so be it. So let all Thine enemies be cast out, and perish, O Lord, for their violence against their brother, let shame cover them; let them be cut-off for ever: But let them, that love Thy Israel, be as the Sun when he goeth forth in his might. Amen.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I thanke you, you have cleared two things unto me, one from his words, the other from his Prayer: (1) That the true Religion is but pretended by the King and his party but Popery is intended. (2) That a wicked mans Curse is to be preferred before his Blessing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
There is a third lesson, which is very pertinent to, and deducible from our last discourse, which I reserve for you to the last. You doe remember you have but the halfe yet, what your senses have reported touching the Parliaments defence of Libertie; That it is a reall defence, truly intended and indeed. I tooke the last first, because I am sure the defence of Liberty is first in the order of our nature, and of time with us. That the Parliaments intentions are the same for the defence of the true Religion, shall be as fully cleared unto you now: And truly I could doe it very quickly in a continued discourse, for it is but clearing unto you the Parliaments actions here also, to be faire and well becomming a Parliament; But because this pretended defence of Religion is the grand accusation, wherewith thine enemies have reproached, O Lord, wherewith th • y have reproached the footsteps of thine Anointed, all Thy faithfull servants in the Land; because, I say, it is the great and grievous accusation and now we have to doe with the mouth that speakes blasphemies, wee must be large at this point. I shall seeme to divert from it sometimes, that we may omit nothing which may helpe to cleare up your understanding in this matter, and to stop the mouth of iniquity, that it may be no more a reproch. The blasphemy is but pointed a • in the Title page, It runnes-out at length thus, through the chiefe part of the Booke, The Parliament doe but pretend the defence of Religion: they intend faction. They countenance Sects and Sectaries▪ Anabaptists &c. such as are condemned by the Lawes of the land; These are their strength in their Armies, together with Papists, [O liar!] and their strength in their House▪ [O monstrous!] They enquire after Truth, but at the wrong doore: [not of the Archbishops and Bishops; [no Ile warr • nt you, not of them that have persecuted the Truth.] nay they do but aske, What is Truth? as Pilate did▪ they doe not meane to stay their answer; they are resolved upon the Question, what they are resolved to doe, they are pretenders to [our Bishops] Religion [Indeed they are not] established by
the Lawes of the Kingdome. [Indeed it is not] but they intend a religion that was never allowed of in the world, unlesse by such empty fellowes as themselves. There is the accusation.

p.hi: How does he make it good?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Nay there he leaves us, f • r hee is no wiser then the Divell his master, he is but an Accuser, this servant of his is no more. But that he is such another, even the same, we will prove presently by the same helps, which formerly we have made use of, and so we enquire touching the Parliaments Actions in this great businesse, The settling of Religion.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Settling! Why Doctor Ferne tells you it is not unsettled, it is an established Religion by the Lawes of the Land.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
You doe not well to interrupt me with Fernes fopperies and fooleries: Religion established by the Lawes of the land! I tell you it must be established by the Law of God, and rule of His Word, or else it will never be established; Besides, you doe unnecessarily trouble me. It is cleared already to all your eyes, That Religion is offended, and more, though I will say no more, for I have said enough. We were enquiring touching the Parliaments Actions in this great and transcendent businesse, the settling of Religion, what they have done touching that matter: or what doe they, that they are questioned for notable hypocrites, to be Pretenders onely to Religion, Intenders of faction; what have they done? What doe they? It is a necessary Question, and onely necessary, such as onely requires answer at this point: for if the Adversary must acknowledge, That the Parliaments Actions in this businesse have beene, and are faire, well becomming a Parliament, then I will affirme before the face of heaven and earth, That Ferne accusing their intentions, is a most malignant wretch, a childe of Satan, an enemy to all goodnesse; nay, a Divell, the very mouth of the Devill, as sure as a true Minister of Christ is an Angell of God, and the mouth of God, so sure. And now if it could be, I would summon up Ferne, this adversary,
or the Divell himselfe to come up now and appeare in this case, and in this accusation; and I would adjure him by the Living God, who has given life and being to His Creatures, a Tongue, Reason and Iudgement, to tell us what he has seene (I doe not say what he has heard, though I durst put him upon that evidence) but what hee has seene in the Actions of the Parliament touching this matter; and as sure as I breathe, I doe nor say J live, none but God saies so, as sure as by His providence over mee, I doe now breathe, so sure I could silence the Divell now as David did silence that evill spirit in Saul once. But because this cannot be, I will deale with my sober man, and reason out the case with him as fotmerly I have done, requiring of him to tell mee with the same regard to his words, as he, has who knowes he speakes them not so much to man, as in the eares of God, to tell me what he has seene, heard and understood, touching the Parliaments Actions in the carrying-on this great worke, the establishing Religion by the Law of God, and rule of His Word; tell me what you have seene, heard and understood?

p.hi: This, whereunto all my outward and inward faculties of body and soule give me the clearest testimony, that they have inquired of The Lord touching this mattter upon their beds, and in their clossets.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That's well; if God is to be enquired of (as indeed we ought to ask at his mouth in every busines) then in this businesse; But now you must not say onely but you must prove what you say, because we have to do with a Dlv • l, an Adversary indeed: how can you tell that they sought God upon their beds, and in their clossets for this thing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
You will not require of mee further then a judgement of charity; for the certainty God knowes, who sees in the darke, and rewards ope • ly. And yet I must not walke by sense onely, though this my sense tells me, they have commanded praying and fasting; they who have commanded this from others, as Hester did, will fast and pray too, and not in the Assemblies onely, but upon the bed, and in the closset: so I judge; and this I know, when the adversarie
has beene cursing, and blaspheming, they have been praying and praising: when the Adversary has beene plundring and spoiling like Beasts of prey, they have beene fasting; and all this I have seene, felt, heard, and understood.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Well, but you doe understand also. That they enquire about Religion, mainly to finde out The right way of Gods worship.

p.hi: Yes, that is all, if God be worshipped aright, all is right.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: But doe you thinke that the way is easily found out?

p.hi: No, for if so, what need seeking to God by prayer and fasting?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yea, but when I aske whether an easie way to finde out, my meaning is, Is it not a very intricate and perplexed way, hard and difficult to finde out?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No sure, I thinke, for it is the Church way, an holy way, straight and direct forward, no by-path, no turnings and w ••
dings in it, (ever the way of the crooked Serpent) paved out by The Lord Christ himselfe) though the stones and way-markes are somewhat worne out as the figures in a Diall by the storming-ha • le and raine) certainly it is more easie to finde out the way, then to walke in it, because it is a straight way, and direct, and we are very prone to turne upon the right hand or the left. But now wee are upon this holy way, the way of Gods worship, I pray you let mee aske you in passage, what are your thoughts touching the Independent way?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Truly I thinke this word Independent is an unhappy word, and not proper, but I know the way is an holy way, and they that are for that way, understand their way to the City very well: I am confident also they meane no other way, but that you were speaking of a Church way, an holy way, straight and direct, paved out by the Lord Christ himselfe, and trod in by the best servants that ever the Lord Christ had upon the earth: For in t • eir desires they follow Christ, and though hand passibus aquis, yet not willingly would they swerve from their Lords foot-steps, no not a haires breadth. But you have prevented my question all this while. Doe you thinke That the Parliament are
fit and comp • tent Iudges of this way of Gods worship?

p.hi: Truly I thinke yes; there are great Lawyers and great Divines there, and these great men are good men too; and why may not they be all fit to judge of this way?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I pray you consider, There is a great darknesse upon the spirits of men, which hides from them the things of God. There is a vaile, as over Moses, so over the things of Christ and way of His worship, which all the hands in the world cannot remove. We must grant also, That the way of his worship and service has layne as a path not used, quite neglected and over shadowed by, I know not what accursed things, the inventions of men, I am sure, and thereby hidden from the eye these (I know not how) many yeares. Besides, there are many Offices belonging to the service and way of Gods worship, and it is a hard and intricate businesse to finde out what these offices are; who are fit, and what graces required for the filling-up of the office, as the word is; so as the officer may make full proofe,2 Tim. 4.5. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That he is completely fitted for the full discharge of his Cure or Office. Therefore, under correction, I thinke that the Parliament are not competent Judges of those matters.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Now I bethinke my selfe, I must grant so much, for they grant it themselves; They have called together Divines, learned men, from all quarters, to enquire of them concerning this way. But now I must put in a word, and tell you what is said touching that matter also; The Parliament has called together men of their owne mindes, as factious as themselves, and have left-out those honest men the Bishops.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
They call God to record upon their soules touching the former part of the accusation, That it is most false; The good (who onely are charged here) had a single eye to Gods glory in their choice. And for the latter part of the accusation it is false too: some Bishops were chosen (though the unfittest men in the world for such a worke, The settling of Religion, who have unsettled it altogether, whereof in due time) but they came not. One came and sate there till he saw the Assembly would goe on in a way
crosse to the Bishops way, so away he went his owne way, though so neere the end of his course. And there were Episcopall men too, more then enough, which have shewne themselves. But all this does prove and set-off the Parliaments Actions touching this matter, to be as faire and as comely as could be expected or desired. They enquired at Gods mouth: there is the point. Then called an Assembly of Divines from all quarters of the Kingdome, to enquire at their mouth. I would aske the Divell now what could they have done more that they have not done? They have made their choice with a single eye for ought appears to the contrary. But if every 12th man in the Assembly now were a Divell, yet the Parliament stands clear in the judgment of every sober man. But what a choice have they made? What an Assembly have we? Such an Assembly as is the envy of all the malignant over the Christian world. Such an Assembly which is the But and Marke at which the Divell, his Bishops, and servants all over the world, doe shoot their arrowes, even bitter words. What thinke you of the Assembly now?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Past all question, if the Divell and all his Bishops and Servants doe hate them, do shoot at them all their arrows, as at a But, then they are the excellent of all the two Kingdomes.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You conclude very well, for as Davids delight was with the Saints, the excellent in the earth: so is the Devills hatred and envie toward them, a cleare testimony to that excellencie in them. But now you doe reserve all due honour to other of Gods Ministers, excellent men a • so, for all cannot be of that Assembly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes sure; but I pray you keepe to the businesse in hand: tell me, what have the Assembly done? what have they settled?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Indeed these are sawcie words. What have they done, and what have they settled? Though this is not to our businesse neither: yet Ile tell you first, They have set a day apart to seeke God. What thinke you of that?

p.hi: It was a good beginning, but what is that to me?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
What is that to you! Indeed you should bee chid:
Is it nothing to you, that they have sanctified a fast all together, Ezra 8 21. (what they have done in private I cannot tell) that they might afflict themselves before their God, to seeke of him a right way; is this nothing to you?

p.hi: No, nothing to me, it is for themselves.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That's true, for themselves, but they are not for themselves; They sanctified a Fast to seeke of the Lord a right way, as for themselves, so for you and me (for us); yea and for our little ones too, and for all our substance; doe you marke that? All our good, all our concernment, all our substance depends upon this seeking a right way of worship: Can you tell what they have done now?

p.hi: No.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Ile tell you: They have done that was never done while there was a Bishop in that Assemblie: nor never would have been done had there been a Bishop there now; They have got up their hearts to God, they are professed seekers of Him, and at His mouth; And what have they obtained? A framablenesse of Spirit; Spirits framed to, and intent upon their worke: Is this nothing, or is it nothing unto you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I spake weaklie, yea wickedlie, I will doe so no more. Yet give me leave to aske you, What hath the Assemblie setled?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I will not give you leave to speake of settling in this unsetled time, which will be yet more unsetled, (it is much that they have found out a way to settle and fixe their owne spirits heavenward) till Bishops are rooted out, and their established Religion cast out and gone, speake not of setling till that be: expect now a continuance of the earth-quake, and blesse God that they are in a right way to settle all at the last, and wait with patience: We have seene things we looked not for, great and terrible things to the adversaries of the Lord, gratious and glorious to His Friends and Servants, as was the turn •• g Jordan back. Blesse we God for what we have seen, and we shall see greater things then these, even a glorious Reformation, doubt it not. But doe not thinke (though nothing is impossible to the Lord) that a Nation shall be converted at once, that all can be done in a day; that matters concerning the true worship, so out of frame, can be brought into frame in one moneth: Rejoice, and be exceeding glad, that there is a framablenesse of hearts, and of words, and of actions, towards this holy way, that they are all of one lip, and have all one shoulder. I should goe on in this diversion from our maine purpose, but I recall my selfe, and demand of you, for that is to our purpose, What have been the actions of the Parliament wherefore they are accused, To pretend the defence of Religion, and intend faction? Tell me, what are their actions now in sight, and before the face of the Christian
world? The adversarie has reported as you heard, tell me what you can report, according to your evidence, from what you have seen, felt, heard, and understood?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That their actions are faire, becomming a Parliament, as white and pure as is the snow in Salmon, for ought I can see, heare, or understand to the contrarie: I speak it from my heart, as in Gods eares.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You have said right, for the Parliament considering they were to consult, and to determine de ardui • regni, concerning the high matters of Gods kingdome, the way and rule of His worship, considering this, they afflicted their soules to seeke of God the right way: He bad them call an Assembly of Divines, to heare, and consider matters, They did accordingly; His Ministers assembled themselves, and they are Seekers too (I meddle not with particular men, or particular actions;) I say the whole Assembly are seekers for this matter, for flesh and bloud cannot reveale this way of worship; They are Seekers unto God night and day, that he would lead them, and carry them in His hand to the end of their vvorke. till He has perfected His worke in them, and by them, for His people, Amen. What say you now?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I acknowledge most heartily, that the Parliaments actions are faire and lovely, every way becomming a Parliament, they are in sight shining, exceeding white as snow.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Heare your Less n now, and apply your heart to it: When you heare a mans words, that these are as becomes a Christian; you see his actions such also as becomes his profession; his whole deportment as adornes the Gospel; (you must waigh him wee call man, as you doe gold, with Allowance, for he is light upon the ballance) but vvhen you heare and see all this▪ doe not you come in with your If now, and with your But; The actions are good, if the heart were not evill; but the mans heart is rotten, his intentions naught: As you regard your name, your profession, your honour, doe not doe so: If you deale so with your brother, you deale with him as the Divel has done with Iob, and as Ferne has dealt with the Parliament; observe your Rule, You must make the fairest interpretation of your brothers actions, saies Master Perkins; and it is verie notable, Your brother has done thus and thus, verie soule actions, but evermore make the fairest interpretation thereof, thus; Such and such are his actions; what his intentions were I cannot tell; nor what I might have done, bad I been under his temptations, I cannot tell that neither. This is a faire interpretation, cast (as a vaile) over a foule action: But now (for I will repeat it againe) are the actions faire, lovelie, as becomming a Christian, are they so? And will you say now, that his intentions are foule, if you doe (you will not say so) but if you doe, I
will say you are a Devill, and that is the sentence I will now passe upon Ferne. The actions of the Parliament are faire and lovely, as becomes a Parliament, who feares God, honours their King, loves their countrey; Ferne accuseth their intentions now: I call God to record now, and all His faithfull Servants in the world, That Ferne is a Devill, a Satan, an Adversarie, an accuser of his brethren; he sees their actions are faire, yet he saies their intentions are foule; he is an accuser of his brethren, he must be cast out, according to his praier, his Curse rather: And so I have done with him, and God give him grace to know what he has done. Amen.

p.hi: I thanke you heartily, Sir, for your good lesson, I hope I shall remember it, and judge no mans heart but my owne.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes that you may, you may judge anothers mans heart; when you heare corrupt words still, and see foule actions still, or mostly such, then you may judge the heart to be yet more corrupt and filthy: when you see a winking with the eyes, a speaking with the feet, a teaching with the fingers, then you may say the heart is naught, Prov. 6.13, 14. frowardnesse and misthiefe is there, for all this makes a commentarie upon the heart, and you may read a commentary, may you not?

p.hi: Yes sure, I may read a Commentarie, but there can be no cleare Commentary upon so darke a Text as the heart, it is the darkest of any in the world.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Very true, yet there is a Commentarie plain enough as aforesaid, which gives you a cleare light into that Text; for example, you may read Fernes heart legible in Text Letters, that frowardnesse, mischiefe, malice, is there, and that he is a verie Devill, and all this you may judge without breach of charitie, for you read it in Text Letters.

I will give you now the Thred of all our discourse hitherto, that you may wind-it-up together, and see your way in and out: Your judgemet • is cleared in point of defence, That Religion is to be defended with the sword; Israels cases are resolved, and they are quit of rebellion, and so are we also; you can tell your selfe, and make report from all your senses, who are dogges and swine, who have trampled upon the Pearle, who have rebelled against Davids house, and have blasphemed God and the King; and you see clearly with all your eies, that the Parliament doe really and indeed intend the defence of Religion and Libertie; you have your lesson too, and are able to read the darkest Text by its Commentarie, and you can make cleare proofe to all the world, that Ferne is a Foole, a Knave, and a Devill: There we left. But I pray you let me aske, Doe you remember all this?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Yes indeed, verie well, I thanke God and you, you have so
cleared it unto me that I cannot forget it; you have taught mee to make use of all my senses, these have put it to my understanding; my understanding hath put it to my memorie, and there it is fast, as under locke and key.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is very well, and fit it is to make use of all our Powers outward and inward; God has lent them us for that end, To enform us what is the good way, and then to fix our foot in it, and make us stable, it is a stormy time, it will try us what bottom and foundation we have, and what constancy of spirit; we see now many tack-about, and take a contrary side, wheele away to the King; because there is preferment in that way (as they call preferment now a daies) The Scholler, if he will be a right man, shall be made a Doctor; The Gentleman a Knight, a Knight a Lord, and the Lord an Earle; A trap, a gin, a snare to catch Woodcocks! But I pray you make use of your senses still, doe not put out the light, that will come-in through those doores; And remember, what gaine is it to sell ones soule for some preferment, and honour in the world, if it could be had now; what gaine I say, to have the favour of a King, with the dis-favour of the Almighty? What gaine to be a Servant to mens lusts, and a slave to the Devill, slighting the service of God, wherein is perfect freedome? Pray you consider of it, and this with it; That it is the greatest honour now, to be the Kings Traitor; the truest obedience, to be accounted a Rebell against him; and it is the greatest dishonour under the Sun, to be a right man for his service, to stand with his loines ready girt, eares bored to receive and do his Commands; and so now we are quit of rebellion, your judgment is cleared, Is it not?

p.hi: Yes but.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Yes and but; Speake out man, are you not satisfied?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, for me thinkes still, yee resist the King.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: See what you say! We cannot contend with Dogs and Swine, we cannot resist Scorpions, but wee must resist the King • for the King sets on the Dogs, and Commands the Scorpion to sting us; and we cannot resist one, but we must resist both; is not that your meaning?

p.hi: Yes sure.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Then wee must let the Dogs fly in our faces, and the swine trample upon the Jewell, and the Scorpions sting us to death; we must suffer all this, must we not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, the Primitive Christians did so, they were Passive still; being Reviled we blesse;1 Cor. 4.12. being persecuted we suffer it. Look you here! There is the other Scripture, which assureth us, that the Primitive Christians did not Resist.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
True, for how could they resist, they had not any considerable
strength on their side (which was in sight) and, which was the want indeed, they had not the Law on their side to warrant their strength, and to put it out: If they served God according to His Word (which they would doe,) if they praied, if they walked humblie before Him, (which they did delight to doe,Humiles sunt, hoc volunt; infirmi sunt, infirmitate laetantur, Salv 8.) then were they torne in pieces: I cannot expresse how cruellie they were dealt withall.

p.hi: And was not the Law open to them? could they not have recourse thither?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No indeed, all this the adversarie did by the knowne (Imperiall) Lawes of the kingdome: Indeed sometimes the Lawes were too short to beare-out their wickednesse, but then they could eeke out the Law at their owne pleasure; for when they found not a Law to justifie what they did, they could finde out a Law to doe what they listed. Blessed be God, it is easier with Christians now then in ancient times; the Primitive Christians lived under those, who would be absolute Monarchs, and ruled as they listed; Christians now are subjects to Kings who are subjects also to God and His Law, and stand as fully charged by the Oath of God to governe his people by law, as his people stand charged to obey by law.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But if the King breake his Oath, is that a warrant for the people to breake theirs?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No, they will not breake Oaths, those firme bands; they never tooke an oath to yeeld-up their throat to Murtherers, nor to suffer dogges to rent them, nor swine to trample upon their Jewell; they never tooke an oath to obey the King, farther then he obeies God; they never swore obedience, or themselves slaves to the lusts of men: Gods people know what power they must obey, a lawfull power; and what they stand charged to resist, a lawlesse power, given-up into the hands of the most violent and bloudie men, dogges, swine and scorpions; these they must resist: If the King now will not shew himself King in the exercise of Kingly power, but will give forth his hands to Swine, and Dogges, and Scorpions, the servants of the Lord will draw their hand from him, that they may not partake with him in his sinnes, and in his plagues; Their vowes are upon them, they have taken the oath of God, that they will approve themselves good subjects to His Kingdome, faithfull Servants to his Church.

p.hi: At, but subjects must approve themselves good subjects is their King, faithfull servants to him.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
So they have done; no such subjects to their King, as those who subject themselves to the law of Christ; none serve their
King so faithfullie, as doe they, who do so serve their God: I should tell you a long storie here, but you shall have the marrow of it only,Trip. Hist. lib. 1. Cap. 7. the result therefrom; Constantius would feele the pulse, and try the temper of his Ministers, how loyall and faithfull they would approve themselves to their only Lord, and his deputed Vice-gerent: And he found some of his Ministers, such as were our Bishops all, very Weather-Cocks, or Tide-Boats, turning with the wind, and running with the streame (which they thought turned;) Constantius observing this, discarded them everie one; thrust them from his side, and out of his Court, using these words; They will never bee faithfull to my Person, who are unfaithfull to their Master and mine: It is a resolved Case ever since there was a King upon Earth, He that Rebels against God, and is a Traitor to his Church, was never good King, nor good Subject. Therefore we conclude, when the King falls away and Rebells against God, all good Subjects must fall from him, they must revolt from him (else they are not good) as the good Priests did from a Rebellious King,2 Chron. 21. who Compelled Judah to walke contrary to God, and so to rush-on upon the Sword in the Angels hand, as you may read at large.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is not much to the purpose, and little to my satisfaction; I understand your opinion is, That the Primitive Christians were Passive, they obeyed by sufferings (for that is an obedience) but their suffering was forced, because they must: I take it, That's your opinion; and that, if the Christians had bad strength or power one their side, then they had resisted; Is not that your opinion?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No, indeed, it is not; you doe not understand me fully, you doe not take all my words, and yet they are but two: I mentioned Power and Law both; I pray you take them together, so they will doe us good; If you take them severally, you destroy the Truth; Power without Law, is as King without Reason; Law without Power is as a King without strength; If you divide these, Ile tell you what I think: that the Primitive Christians would not have resisted their Lords, if they had had no more but power on their side. But this I know, had they had power & law both (for there is their warrant) on their side they would have resisted; they would not have indured those insolencies, Those tre • dings down by the foot of pride I am confident of thats truly there is so much said, and so fully for the clearing of this, that I know not what to say more; To say more, is but to say what has been said, over and over againe, so I have done.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Nay, I pray you heare me, while I tell you what a learned Divine (for I thinke it is he, Th. At. Rothe
• am. that has discovered a den of Thieves) told mee in reference unto this Scripture; The Sword saies hee, is one of Gods sore Iudgments, so
are wild Beasts; God has now a designe upon the whole land, To destroy some, to correct others, and to purifie a third sort as in the fire, The King (some are so bold as to say) as the Viall of Gods wrath: and the Rebels the hands of the King; (some call them wild Beasts) grant it to bee so, yet the Parliament and their party doe Rebell against God and the King, in making any resistance; for indeed they doe oppose the great designe of God, which is, To punish and correct us for our sins, by the King, the man of his hand, wherewith God will execute the heat of his displeasure against a God provoking people, what doe you say to this?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I will reply nothing to such a fellow; if it be he that discovered the den of Thieves, hee fell foule upon the Covenant, and told a Kinsman of mine (a man in yeeres, but a child in understanding) That he might take the Oath of God,
Gen. 34.23. as the Sechemites did take Circumcision, with references to their private wealth: So he might lift up his hand, and subscribe his Name with Ifs and Buts, with reservations and by-respects; So he was assured he might do,A conscientious man may scruple at the Covenant and refuse it, but he cannot advise as Rotheram has done, and be an honest man. and hee rejoiced That such a Discoverer of Thieves, was of his mind, as wise a man as himselfe: But I did assure him upon that assurance he gave to mee, That Rotherham his ghostly Father, was the most notable Theefe in all the Den; he gets no answer from me; But goe you and say thus unto him. A mad dog may fly at your throat, a viper may hang upon your hand, A den of Thieves (now you have discovered them) may breake into your house, Rob and spoile, and murther you and yours there; if so it fall out, you can consider, It is for your sin; God is just, you must not stave off the Dog, not shake off the Viper not resist the Robbers, tell him so.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Indeed I will not, I will not exalt folly; I will not declare my selfe to bee a Foole or a Knave before all the Congregation; doubtlesse so the Person will account of me, and call me so too, if I should speake unto him in your words; That hee must give his throat to the mad dog; his hand to the Viper; open his door to the Robbers; doubtlesse he would call mee foole and a knave too, for saying so.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Very well, the person has answered himself. Now because you have made some Discovery here of a notable Thiefe, the chiefest in all the den; Ile give you some advice; doe not hearken to such fellowes who oppose the Covenant, reject them, and their opinion: Doe not let will rule thou, but reason, refined, and rectified by the Rule and Will of God▪ which will teach you to serve God, and His providence; to hold fast the truth, and contend for the Faith; very nature will teach you in other matters to resist the Devill, to stave off a Dog, To shake off a Viper; To drive from you those Swine, To resist Scorpions.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am fully resolved, and it is in the purpose of my heart, (The Lord who put it there, keepe it there) To renounce my owne wisdome, and 〈◊〉 follow no guide farther, then I can follow him with mine eye, and see clearely, That he walks by his rule. I am perswaded now that it may be said of the wisest man upon the face of the earth, that if he be his owne teacher, he has a foole to his Master.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Well, but before I conclude I shall command your answere to a verie grave Question, whereunto I make way thus: There are but two sides or parties in the land, The King and his partie, The Parliament and their party; A cursed division it is, and cursed are they that have divided them, though indeed, and in true construction, the King in his politicall capacitie cannot be divided from his Parliament: But we see the rent, and so it seemes to be now, and these two sides and parties stand with swords pointed each at other; This is the Question now, Who shall have the day or victory?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Alas, why doe you aske me such a question, I cannot tell what to think; this I know,
• ella geti nullos placuit habitura triumph •• . who ever shall have the victorie, neither shall have the triumph.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You are mistaken now, that side which has the victorie shall have great cause of triumph too (in the Lord): but answere my question, Which side shall have the victorie?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Indeed I cannot tell; I can tell that the Parliaments sword stands p • inted against Dogges, Swine, and Scorpions; but I consider the strength that Dogges have, especially when they are mad; and what tumults Swinish men make when they are drunk with rage; I perceive what is the force and fraud of Serpents; I consider also withall, how they multiply upon us like fishes: these Dogges, and Swine, and Scorpions, are scattered through every quarter of the land, and yet conjoyned and folded like thornes together, and all to make the house of Esau a flame, and the house of Jacob as stubble: Therefore in my eye the Parliament and their side are small, and (in my apprehension) their case was more hopefull two yeares agoe then now: Then I thought God would end the warre quickly, He would thrust-downe his ad •• rs ••• es, and lift-up his friends suddenly: But now when we seeme to set our faces beavenward, and to come-up to Gods termes, He seemes to goe backe, the breach seemes to be made wider, and the Scale turnes in sight to the Kings side; for all the Irish — and the Divels with them, are laid upon the Scale to outballance the Scots. Indeed I see little hope, Friends are few, and enemies are many, and increase every day: hear you not what droves and heards of Beasts (of prey) break-in; I say not well (break-in) are called-in, and answere their call every day? And our brethren the Scots, our strong arme whereon we leane, these are not come: Come they will, that is sure, for however they are blasphemed, none so faithfull to God and his cause as are they: but they will come too late sure, all will be lost first. And so I have formed, and shaped
my thought unto you, but your judgement is more cleared in these matters, pray you what thinke you?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You shall heare, not what I thinke, but what I know; but I must chide you first, and my selfe more hearilie: How doe we walke man! by sight, and so wee speake what lieth uppermost: we say

1. That dogges, and swine, and scorpions, are scattered through the whole land, and yet are folded together like thornes, to doe mischiefe. No strange thing, the Church has ever been as sheep among wolves, yet not devoured; and so the right hand of the Lord has been magnified in their preservation.

(2.) See our selves speake, adversaries we say are strong, friends weake: indeed we speake as fooles speake, and falslie; the contrarie is true; The adversaries are weake, and Gods friends are strong: It is a resolved case, They are weake as water, as a Doe without a heart, who have provoked God, though in sight as strong as Goliah, and as completelie armed as was hee Cap a pe, as wee say, from head to foot.

(3.) Observe how wise we are! we thought God would have ended the warre quickly: Who bad us thinke so? we have beene warring against God, vve have vvalked contrarie to Him all our yeares, and vve thought He vvould vvalke contrarie to us but one yeare. We thought the Lord would but suffer the fire of His wrath to kindle upon us, and no more, Hee would put it out presently: Who bad us thinke so? Not the Lord, nor His Word, nor His Servants, that speake as the Oracles of God; for is our drosse and our scum so small, that a small fire of short continuance wil serve the turne! We have been breaking His Law these (I know not how) many yeares; vve thought the Lord would make a breach upon us onely, and make it up presentlie: We are fooles for thinking so. we have been grieving His Spirit (by our lying vanities) I know not how long, yet we thought the Lord would grieve our Spirits a moneth, and no longer, He would comfort us the next moneth. we tooke away the Day of His Rest, we profaned that Day, never people did as we did; yet we thought the Lord would make us Restlesse, He would disquiet us but a verie little while: Surely these are vaine thoughts.

(4.) See how ignorantlie we speake; God goes backe! God does not goe backe vve goe backe; vve change, there is no change in God; vvhat He did last yeare, and this yeare, are the same He decreed to doe before the vvorlds were in being: We goe backe, God goes forward, and carries on His worke like a God in all His peoples sight.

p.hi: Say you so! But I told you the breach seemes wider; There is a firme union betwixt the King and the — Irish; and you know what followes, our burthens are like to be encreased.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
If we poore ones could hearken, (but we cannot for anguish of spirit and cruell bondage) if we could observe, here were the best signe that ever vvas beheld since Israel vvas in Egypt; for as then, when the Task-masters rage encreased, brickes and burdens vvere multiplied, Moses came; so it will be now, vvhen the Irish are called-in, now God is called-in; they hasten, and God hastens, (what to do?) To get Himselfe a Name, and an honour, as then, so now, over this —Egyptian host, them and their King: It is so, but our eyes are closed, our hearts shut up, therefore are wee so mistaken and so disheartned. The Lord Christ prophesied of these verie times, when Kingdome shall rise against Kingdome, when His people shall be hated of all for His names sake,
Luk. 21.10.17. when the dayes of vengeance will come. Let me aske this question; What doe we now?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ile tell you what I doe, let others answere for themselves: I doe nothing but sit still and complaine of the Rebels.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You doe not answere me to my minde, and so you put me to the trouble of another question, upon this supposition; Your neighbour lets loose his masti • e-dog upon you, the dog does like a dogge, flies at your face, and bites off your nose, you complaine now, of vvhom? that is the question.

p.hi: Of my neighbour, upon just reason.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You say vvell; and for the verie same reason should you complaine of your selfe, and your owne rebellions; for your rebellions have called these Rebells in, and given them power over you. But to my former question, you see the times the same that vvere prophesied-of, my question is, What is your posture now?

p.hi: My heart failes me for feare, my countenance is cast downe, I am in no good posture of defence.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Indeed I thought so; I see my owne posture, and the posture of the Nation in yours; most contrarie all this to what should be, and to vvhat the Lord chargeth us to doe. Our countenance is cast downe, vve are charged to looke up; our head hangs down like a bullrush, the Lord commands, saying, Lift up your heads. We expect now destruction upon destruction, the Lord Christ bids us expect now deliverance upon deliverance, for great troubles evermore have ushered them in. See (I pray you) this is the good vvord of the Lord, When these things come to passe, then look-up, and lift up your heads, for your redemption drawes nigh. See again, how good the Lords words are, and how contrarie our hearts and their posture are unto them, for

p.hi: Doe you thinke so?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: I said I vvould tell you, not vvhat I think, but vvhat I know: I know it shall be so, as sure as the Lord our God is Lord over the Lords of the vvorld; so sure as the King of Saints is King over the Kings of the earth, so sure. But I shall impart no more of my knowledge til we have chid our hearts more.

(6.) We said, the Irish come in apace, and our hearts mis-give us: We must chide our hearts, and say, it is not onely just, but good it should be so: For Gods people have contracted much filth, they are growne soule and nastie: Indeed we should welcome these Scullions (as sent to us from God) whose end is by them to scoure and whiten His Church: Amen. Dan. 11.35.

(7.) We rise and fall, as our friends stand, and our helpers come-in, as appeares by that you spoke even now concerning the Scots: I pray as heartily as I can, The Lord blesse the Scots, They have appeared for the Lord alwaies, as His matters have required: Now, the same Lord appeare to them, and for them, and in them; let not any of them, that have engaged themselves in their Lords quarrell, let n •• o • e of them vvant an Advocate with the Father; They have set their affection to the cause of their God, now the Lord set his heart upon them, and everie one of them that have so done, and blesse them as He did His servant Abraham, make them and their house a blessing: Amen. But they cannot be a blessing unto us for mighty Reason.

p.hi: Ah Lord! not a blessing to us; why doe you say so? and what is your reason?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
I have no other reason but from your owne mouth, and that is a mightie reason: You said, that the Scots are our strong arme, and we leane upon them; then I say, they cannot be a blessing; wee may call for their hands, and use them, but we must not make them
our Arme: we must chide our hearts off this arme, and bring them up to fixe and leane on Gods Arm, if we looke to be held-up. Judge you of this matter, supposing your case, this: You lay all the bulke and waight of your bodie upon a reed, which the least puffe of wind does bend▪ will your strong supporters (your legges) doe you any service now? you know they cannot. It is so, if we make flesh our arme, if we leane thereon, the everlasting Armes withdraw themselves from unde • neath; and they must fall, vvho have not underneath the everlasting Armes. But vvhat weake hearts have we, because still leaning on the armes of flesh, therefore how floating up and downe, as the ebbing and flowing waters! If the arme of flesh be strong we are strong; if that be weake, vve faint: The Lord help us and stablish our hearts, Amen, that He may bee our Arme vvhereon to leane; and then bring-in our brethren▪ as upon Eagles wings. Amen.
8. We said in our haste, Help will come too late: Wee must chide our hearts for saying so; Help never came too late unto the Church, it comes ever in the fittest time, in season.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But (Sir) though you will not tell me your thoughts Ile tell you mine, such as feares and terrours round-about have shaped them; these are my thoughts: That if the Lord does not deliver us this yeare, vve shall be all destroied next yeare; the sword must eat us up or the famine: It must be so, there is little hope it can be otherwise.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Indeed you must be chid It will be so, and, It must be so: How doe you know the thoughts of the Lord? I doe assure you, that in the very same yeare which starre-gazers thought vvould prove the most seasonable yeare to the vvorld, the floud came, and swept the vvorld away. I confesse we may make shreud and sad conjectures, and just cause there is of feare, when we looke into our selves, and abroad into the world.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So say I too; I judge of vvhat will be no further then •• ason and sense assures me: The robbers are in everie field, and so mischievous they are, they take away whole Te • mes at once, and what they cannot consume they spoile: The husband-man cannot sow, then I am sure he cannot reap; there must be a famine next yeare.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Truly you should bee dealt sharply withall; can you tell what encrease the Lord may give to those places, where these Robbers, spoilers, mischievous villaines, have not come? I pray you consider, The servants of the Lord are now helping their Lord against those mighty hunters to thrust them forth of the Land, and to take the prey out of their hand; an acceptable work, is it not?

p.hi: Yes, but i • is impossible.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Now ile chide sure: dare you say that is impossible to be done, which the Lord does every day, according to his good Word unto his people? The Captives of the mighty men, shall bee taken away,
Esa. 49.25, 26. and the prey of the terrible shall be delivered, for, and so forth; looke you there, consider on it, and you will speak no more as a fool speaketh. Answer you my Question now▪ This helping the Lord against the mighty Adversaries of the Lord is it an acceptable worke to the Lord, or is it not?

p.hi: I must needs answer, it is an acceptable worke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Well, another question; The Servants of the Lord have, by raying in prayer, gained one Lip and Shoulder, they are now intent, and in a ready frame of spirit towards this great worke; The finding out of the right way of G • ds Worship; The clearing the VVorship of God from the Bishops blasphemies; and setling Religion. What think you, Is this worke according to the will and Command of God, and to the heart of his people, is it?

p.hi: Yes doubtlesse, the Servants of the Lord cannot be better employed for their Lord, then in this worke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: You say well; And if your servants lay out themselves for you, in the faithfull discharge of their care and trustt; and in an Answerablenesse to all your lawfull commands, you will provide for these Servants, and protect them too, if it bee in your power will you not?

p.hi: Yes sure, you need make no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Nor need you make any doubt, but God will provide for you and protect you, if you bee his faithfull servant, engaged upon his worke, if you lay your selfe-out for him, all you have, and all you are (for all is from him) if you lay-out all for him, He will provide for you sure enough; you are carelesse and secure at that point, a e you not?

p.hi: N • ind • ed.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
No indeed! why then you doe thinke, that God will not do (you cannot question His power) for his faithfull servants, as you would doe for yours. I pray you thinke againe, and you will thinke more wisely. I wil advise you now, and tell you what I know presently; let not your heart bee troubled, chide distrustfull thoughts about the Famine and the Sword; be assured, that faith feares not a Famine, it laughs at the Sword;Fides famem non timet. Iob. 5. it is not afraid of the beasts of the Earth: doe your worke, lay out your selfe wholly for God and His Cause; doe your worke so, as to adorne your name, and the Gospel, and your profession; doe it so, and bee no longer sad, nor troubled about the burt the Adversary will doe to us, this or the next yeare
Bee assured, God will doe us good; we serve a good Master; wee have a gracious, a glorious King in Heaven. And so I • e tell you what I know; for I know the word of God is true. This is the word of the Lord; My Servants shall eate, but yee (the Lord speakes to Dogs, and Swine, and Scorpions, Robbers, Murtherers,) but yee shall be hungry; My Servants shall drinke, but you shall be thirsty; My Servants shall rejoice, but you shall be ashamed: My servants shall sing for joy of heart, Esa. 67.13.14 15. but you shall cry for sorrow of heart, and you shall leave your name for a curse unto my Chosen, sayes the Lord. And so we will conclude against the Adversaries, and for the friends and servants of the Lord, Iob. 5.12, 13, 14, 15. The Lord shall disappoint the devices of the crafty, so that their hands cannot performe their enterprise, &c. and so on to the 15 verse: But he saveth the poore from the sword, from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty. There is more yet, they are pronounced happy, who are vexed with briars, and grieved with thornes, and corrected (it is but a correction) with scorpions; Vers. 17. for the same Lord who made His people sore, will bind them up; and He that wounded them with one hand, will make whole with both hands, Yet this is not all, Vers. 11. The Lord will set on high those which be low, that those which mourne may be exalted: How high? to the highest exaltation that is imaginable,It is the same word with that, Psal. 3 2. which wee translate help. This word signifies safety here amidst Wolves; That word in the Psalm, has a notable increase of a letter and vowells, which implies a double salvation here and hereafter; The great Priviledge of the Godly. * exalted to safety. Looke you there, what can the dogges, and swine, and scorpions, doe against these servants of the Lord? Their Tongue, their Feet, and their Sting, cannot reach these servants of the Lord, they are Exalted to safety. Hearken what the Lord saies once more, all ye that are fearefull in heart, and be no more fearfull nor full of care; be diligent, and do good, and bee no further troubled; Hearken: He that scattered Israel will gather him, and keep him as a shepheard doth his flocke: All they that devoure thee shall be devoured, and all thine adversaries, every one of them, shall goe into captivity; and they that spoile thee shall be a spoile; and all that prey upon thee I will give for a prey: for I will restore health unto thee, and I •• ll h •• le thee of thy wounds, saith the Lord, Ier. 31.10. and 30.16, 17. Amen.

div.head: A POSTSCRJPT.
div.p: I Have much exceeded my allowance here, and yet a good portion of my undertaking is behind, touching Arch-Bishops, &c. The reason is, because the case of Rebellion, unexpectedly was cast in here, upon the face of all the faithfull in the World; Jsraels two cases also, and the practice of the primitive Christians, together with Ferns blasphemy, all this to make it our case, and to prove our practice to bee rebellious. I doe not doubt to say now, That I have cleared Israels cases, and them of rebellion, our owne practice also to be now as justifiable in resisting, as was the practice of the primitive Christians in suffering▪ And Ferns blasphemy against God and the King, is set so close upon his forehead, that all the water in the Sea shall not wash it off; I have but a request, That he who reades, would read it all, and in order, else nothing at all.

The other portion of my undertaking, Ile give forth intire of its self, with as full, and yet as short a hand as I can. Surely if the sentence from mans law, which is but an abstract from the Law of God, and should hold a conformity thereunto, be as quick against these kind of men, as it is from
Gods mouth, wee shall dispatch them quickly. But it is considerable, that the Bishops Government is the greatest Idol in the Land, and has multiplied Idolls all over the Christian world; And now the Kings of the earth doe weep over them, so doe the Merchants. Here will be a Scuffle, a pleading for them; very little will be said for the Arch-Bishops, more for the Bishops; much for the defence of some, why they should not suffer with the rest, who have offended Rome as eagerly in shew, as others have defended her indeed; much also for the continuing of the name, and of their Office: We shall argue clear against all this, find all guilty; name and thing, and all to be cast out. And all this for the honour of the (Scripture) Bishop, and for the confusion of the lord. Amen.
